This is feces coming out of the cesspool of contemporary American (((media))).It started as a fairly entertaining series, but eventually deteriorated into a monstrosity that feeds off cultural references, has no plot, and increasingly relies on absurd violence and vulgarity to compensate for lack of imagination.You see, in the past, people would actually produce original content, be it films or TV-series. Then Family Guy came along and exploited these original works for amusement purposes. But once these references are exhausted, then what? What kind of culture produces nothing of value, and seeks nothing but cheap, brainless entertainment in the form of reference to things that were made in the past and actually had value? As the series draws ever closer to its eventual end, I expect the final episodes to consist of nothing but endless farts. And that would be a fitting image of the state of culture today.

This is not the best animated show out there. It is a few notches under the Simpsons and Futurama (the new triumph on the network, though they don't seem to think so putting it below prime time), but a couple of notches above the PJs and the god awful King of the Hill, often the most painful show to watch on television. I can understand why people would not like this show. Its plots are almost nonsensical. Plot points occur at breakneck speed, and there are quick pauses for cheap jokes, funny flashbacks, and especially pop culture references. These pop culture references are the main reason I watch the show. The Simpsons and Futurama are abundant with them, too, but The Family Guy usually has several a minute. Perhaps you don't like that, and that's okay. I guess you could call me a bona fide geek, loving to point out the references. I love the fact that The Simpsons has parodied/referenced Citizen Kane, a film which many will call the best film of all time, about 5 different times. At least 2 whole episodes of that show were based around sections of the plot of Citizen Kane.Futurama parodies/references more recent pop culture references. I've  seen Armageddon and ID4, among others. They are often funny, but it lacks the obscurity in its references that the Simpsons has.Now there is the Family Guy. Well, its references bounce from old movies, children's literature, retro 70s camp television, Looney Toons, and especially commercials. It might not have made much sense to some viewers, but when Peter Griffin chased a sock stealing faun through the landromat drier into Narnia, I laughed hard. When Brian (the talking dog) was chasing around the Gravy Train, I laughed hard, even though the many people with whom I was watching this show (when they were laughing constantly beforehand) were totally silent. I laughed a lot when Meg was handed a bomb, it exploded, and she spontaneously had a duck bill on the other side of her head. There were a lot of episodes near the end of the first season which were just plain terrible, so I quit watching it after that. I have checked in thrice since it started its second season, and there wasn't an episode I disliked. Now I'm going to have to add it to my regular schedule. I just wish Fox would take King of the Hill away and exchange its time slot for that of Family Guy. Then, with Futurama-Family Guy-Simpsons, I'd be completely set.
I think this show is one of the best animated th shows, it's so hilarious. Seth MacFarlane is Legend.

After viewing this show, it has not only well drawn caricatures but a machine gun pace. Often it pops out punch lines so fast that even though not every line hits the target, there are enough good ones to over whelm any clinkers.This show lampoons any & every subject. Baby Stewie is a classic type of the baby who can do do it all. The show starts with a theme setting that reminds me of first All In The Family & then a big musical number. The humor is so good, that early on it even lampooned the Clinton's & didn't raise an eyebrow with all the Pro-Clinton media types.In a way, I am not so sure that this type of comedy is the kind which dominated Vaudeville many years ago. The show always goes for the direct & quick laugh by being absurd, & more often than not, it is very successful.
Hard to believe this series has been around since 1999. It's a bit like South Park- don't watch if you take yourself seriously or are easily offended!

When I first watched this a decade ago, I wondered, "Who created this?!" and, "What mental hospital did they escape from?" Because "Family Guy" is not quite like any other show I've ever seen. A sense of humour like a fist in the face and a bunch of head cases for the roster of, ahem, "people", that make up these characters are taking animation to a new, hilarious depravity.Seth Macfarlane and Alex Borstein are at least half of the voices in a typical episode (or seem to be). How a blithering idiot of a Rhode Island dad and husband, an erudite pooch and an evil infant modelled on some cross between Rex Harrison and Satan all come from the same voice-over genius is one of television's great mysteries. Borstein is the "sensible" mom and wife, as well as so many other females who pop up for a couple seconds or the better part of half an hour. Her talents get a much broader and deeper workout here than on "Mad TV", where a lot of material wasn't fully suited to her incredible energy and intelligence.Some jokes make me wince (and still laugh) years after first hearing them (like anything involving "Diff'rent Strokes" or the late Bob Crane). I don't know if FOX has a censor at all or if they're just asleep when some really way out lines are written into any script. Things sure have changed since Jack Paar got into trouble for saying "water closet" back in the early 60s!It's mind boggling that this is in syndication and more popular now than "The Flintstones" were forty years ago. Wherever "cartoons" are headed in the 21st century, you can bet the power of disc sales will make execs pay much closer attention to whatever they're ready to cancel from now on. The voices of millions are being heard at cash registers!My favourite stories so far are really like an unofficial hour of two episodes. 1:"The Thin White Line" and 2: "Brian Does Hollywood", where after developing a cocaine habit while working as a drug sniffing canine for the Quahog police department, he goes out to smoggy California to live with his cousin Jasper and break into the movies. Better than any others for summing up the "everybody is fair game for a joke" ethos we've come to know and love (or despise).

I personally watched All Of It's Episodes,
It Helped me A lot To Get Rid Of My Stress.

Family guy is an animated comedy about a dysfunctional family living in Quahog, in Rhode Island. The family is headed by Peter griffin, the absolute definition of repulsive. He's grossly overweight, idiotic, unsanitary, and overall, incapable of being everything he is. His wife, Lois is everything a 42 year old mother of 3 kids wants to be - Hot, level headed, and smart. the 2 don't match, but that's one of the show's many jokes. Their children are Meg, an overweight unpopular girl who does everything that dramatic teens do, Chris, who takes after his father in almost every way, Stewie, the Baby who is always trying to kill his mother, and seems to have more brains than the whole family combined. finally rounding out the family is Brian, the family dog, however, unlike most dogs, Brian talks, dates human women, and has a sense of humor as dry as his martinis.The episodes usually involve 2 or 3 of the characters in a situation where they end up making crazy decisions. Peter goes abstinent, Lois learns karate, Chris gets the family in witness protection, meg becomes a lesbian, and the baby and the dog go on so many adventures together we've lost count.There are 2 main gags the show lives on - Musical numbers and cutaway gags. Surely you know what a musical number is. On the show, Brian and Stewie sing a song and dance around like it's the 1940's. The cutaway gags are a regular occurrence, where a character describes their problem as "Worse" or "better than" and then they usually say a celebrity's name, and what they did, which usually produces a funny clip.Overall, Family guy is a raunchy, politically incorrect half-hour of laughter and we wouldn't have it any other way.

What a load of tripe this show is. And it's in syndication virtually 24/7. It's dreadful to look at because it's so poorly and lazily drawn. Its flashbacks are incredibly lame and unfunny. Story structures don't exist. If they do, they're unresolved. Certain scenes, as unfunny as they are, are inexplicably drawn out for minutes on end. Credit to Seth Macfarlane on his voice work (because every one else just plain sucks), but too bad he's got nothing interesting or funny to say. Watching this show is like watching any random commercial - you glance at it, and then it's erased from your memory forever. Nothing sticks. Pre-pubescent teens are in heaven because of it's potty humour, however, anybody with a braincell would dismiss this in a heartbeat. I can't believe the Fox network actually did something right (for once) for cancelling it. But it's Fox, and they resurrected it. What a shame that The Simpsons have to share the same network with these buffoons. South Park, the greatest animated show of all time, will steer clear.
I Love Family Guy And I Am A Fan Of It, I mean my parents let me watch the show since is good and Seth Macfarlane Your A Genius, For Making This! Please Everyone Check Out This Show! Is cool...

People have been watching this for years but I was always hesitant and never gave it a chance until this last year with my friend. She put it on and it's seriously my favorite show right now. I've never had a show where I laugh in every single episode! Plus it's been on the air for over 19 seasons and it's still hilarious! I absolutely love Family Guy! It's the type of show where you'll rewind parts over and over because you're laughing so hard.

No idea how this show is so popular! Completely trashy, immature humour that is inappropriate for kids and unappealing to adults.The fact that this show is so popular really shows how our society is declining.This show seems to try being "edgy" to be funny, using primarily offensive jokes. The worst part is that some kids watch this show growing up. I shudder to think of how messed up those kids will be if they grow up finding THIS show funny!How can the garbage on this show actually be found funny by people? One of the world's mysteries, I guess.Don't waste your time on this mess of a show.

A cultural reference joke, a nasty repulsive joke, and a sex joke. Then the same all over again. Then more of the same. Then the episode's end. This is simply the forever format of Family Guy. And I hate it!We have nearly the same Simpsons family, yet with less interesting characters, a talking dog and sophisticated baby, and no ironic city. So it's a less comic copy of The Simpsons. And unlike The Simpsons warmth and meanings, Family Guy is made for kicks only. So it's clearly a heartless and mindless Simpsons too!There are not much of situations to make you laugh, only jokes; and they're divided into 2 kinds. The first is imaginative and snappy but mostly juvenile and mean. Speaking of mean; I think this is one of the meanest shows when it comes to mock at celebrities. The second is flatly unfunny and horrendously boring. Hence, it's rare when one joke works! The cultural references are too many to stand. It takes a very dedicated "American" TV viewer, or historian, to get. And dirty humor and sex are used in sick ways. OK. I won't wonder. What do I expect from a show that draws its lead character's chin as testicles!Although the always petulant, British talking, sophisticated baby is a different character that could make a comic show of its own, but it's used in such an annoying way. Everything he says or does is unfunny, rather disturbing, which turns him into a real creep!In terms of the drawings, the level of creativeness is low. The side characters seem the same. And as for the backgrounds, there is no creativeness or caring in the first place.This is The Simpsons poor imitator who doesn't think in anything but making laughs, doesn't make laughs outside cultural references, repulsiveness, sex, and doesn't make these very laughs decent along the way. In brief, the difference between The Simpsons and Family Guy is like the one between The Defiant Ones (1958) and Black Mama, White Mama (1972)!My Verdict: Small part of its comedy works, the rest is a mix of cheapness and ugliness. Take it from me; watch The Simpsons, it is way better, unless you love odious exploitation, and trash TV.P.S: This shoddy clone has a shoddier clone for itself; and I mean none other than The Cleveland Show. It's like coping badly from an already bad copy. Nevertheless, it has one advantage; it makes Family Guy look good!

This show is so American. I don't even know how can a show be more American. It depicts American culture and symbols. The story plot revolves around the American lifestyle but never become boring and set in a routine (it maybe that I only watched the best episodes according to a list on google). I would recommend anyone who likes to get to know American culture and to get a few laughs during the process.

I've heard that "Family Guy" has been pulled from television? Don't know if it's true or not, but "Family Guy" has/had so much potential, the difference between "Family Guy" and "The Simpsons" is that "Family Guy" isn't really based for all ages, it's far more crude and less subtle. I really like "Family Guy" it is original in places, and in a world where cartoons have to compete with "The Simpsons" that's saying something.

When Family Guy first debuted back in 1999, it was absolutely brilliant, and for three seasons was consistently excellent, with some of my personal favourite episodes being "Chitty Chitty Death Bang", "Da Boom", "Holy Crap", "Road To Rhode Island", "There's Something About Paulie", "Road To Europe" and "Ready Willing And Disabled".While the characters were pretty much all good in their own way (except Meg, who, let's face it, was an annoying brat), my favourite character was easily Stewie, who , despite being a baby, was also a homicidal evil genius obsessed with killing his own mother. BRILLIANT! Most of the side characters were hilarious as well, particularly Quagmire.After 3 excellent seasons, however, it was cancelled. This isn't exactly a bad thing, however, as many other sitcoms have lasted a short while and have been remembered as some of the greatest sitcoms of all time, the biggest example of that being Fawlty Towers. If FG had stayed cancelled it would be remembered as one of the greatest shows of all time.Unfortunately, it came back. BIG MISTAKE! Don't get me wrong. Season 4 was very good, with excellent episodes such as "The Cleveland-Loretta-Quagmire", "Petarded", "Peter's Got Woods", "PTV", "The Fat Guy Strangler", "The Father, The Son And The Holy Fonz" and the fantastic "Stewie Griffin: The Untold Story" trilogy. However, S4 wasn't exactly as consistent as the first 3 seasons.It was Season 5 were it really began to run out of steam, being merely an "alright" season with a very mixed quality of episodes. By this point, Seth Macfarlane had also started to change many of the good things about the show, transforming Stewie's character from an evil genius to a repressed homosexual, and making Peter more and more stupid. Despite this, there were still some good episodes such as "Peter's Two Dads" and "Meet The Quagmires". Season 6 was more or less the same. Despite containing the absolute masterpiece that was "Stewie Kills Lois/Lois Kills Stewie" (My two favourite Family Guy episodes by the way) the rest of the season was kind of meh. Season 7 was yet again underwhelming, with the only standout episodes being "I Dream Of Jesus" and "We Love You, Conrad".Then we got to Season 8, and this is when the show started to become a giant load of horses**t. Not one SINGLE episode in Season 8 was even funny in the slightest and the show became way too vulgar and offensive, with the biggest examples being "Dial Meg For Murder", "Quagmire's Dad", the RUBBISH Star Wars parodies and "Peter-assment". Season 9 was again terrible, despite containing two very good episodes ("And Then There Were Fewer" and "Road To The North Pole". Season 10 was again the same. Despite some really good episodes like the fantastic "Back To The Pilot" and "Mr. And Mrs. Stewie", they couldn't make up for the rest of the season, which contained such travesties as "Seahorse Seashell Party" and "Screams Of Silence: The Story Of Brenda Q". And Seasons 11 and 12 were both completely terrible all the way through, with ZERO redeeming qualities. So I have made the decision to stop watching.In conclusion, Family Guy was a once great show that, just like The Simpsons, has become a giant load of crap. But for once being a fantastic show, I'm going to give it an 8/10.

Here's Quagmire's take on a vaudeville musical number :Make em laugh, make em laugh; Don't you know all the world loves to laugh; I always try to find the hottest chick in the place; I crack her on the noggin with a lamp or a vase; And then when she's unconscious I do stuff to her face; Make em laugh, make em laugh, make em laugh.Not really the Simpsons is it?The writing is top notch, but the plot often meanders to wherever the best gags are - pretty much stream of consciousness stuff. They cram an enormous amount of risqué humour, obscure pop culture references, and plot twists into twenty minutes, but some people might find it a bit much. Personally I think it will go down as a cult classic.

Family Guy used to be a great show, but unfortunately, the writers started to lose their ideas about the show. The show started out amazingly, but somewhere around Season 12, the show started to go downhill. Some episodes of the show today shouldn't even be a full episode, rather just one scene. Plus, Seth MacFarlane always shoves his beliefs down our throats. The show completely fell from grace a long time ago, I don't even understand why FOX has the need to keep airing this show anymore.

Honestly, up until its 2002 cancellation I would have deemed this as a decent show that definitely had a good run, albeit a short one... Yet, whenever I may happen upon an airing of this show after its return, I can't help but feel disgusted at the pathetically large effort MacFarlane's show puts in to get laughs out this mind-numbing dreck.It is in no way as clever as it used to be, and no longer retains any of the originality it used to have, and to be honest, every time I see it now it reminds me of the classic "SIMPSON'S DID IT" episode of South Park (which is an actually decent show that is both intellectually stimulating and controversial - a good combination).Anyways, I'd rather not list off the many flaws within the characters and the writing in general, since that would take all night... but I will say that Seth MacFarlane needs to quit before he ruins the minds of society altogether

If there was no Simpsons or South Park, this could probably be the best cartoon series ever created. Creator Seth MacFarlane, who also voices Peter Griffin, Brian Griffin, Stewie Griffin, Glen Quagmire and Tom Tucker and many others has created a great adult comedy cartoon. Also starring Alex Borstein as Lois Griffin and Loretta Brown, Mila Kunis as Meg Griffin, Seth Green as Chris Griffin and Neil Goldman and regular guest Jennifer Tilly as Bonnie Swanson. Basically its the same format as Simpsons, a family that have misadventures, a fat dad and each member having their own individual happenings. The only difference is that it has a baby and a dog, that can actually talk. And its like South Park because of some bad language and violence included. Guests have included Drew Barrymore, Haley Joel Osment, Jay Mohr, Gene Simmons, Carrie Fisher, Patrick Duffy, Mary Kay Bergman and Will Ferrel. It has won 2 Emmys for Outstanding Music and Lyrics and Outstanding Voice-Over Performance, and it has been nominated for 3 Outstanding Animated Program (For Programming Less Than One Hour) awards and Outstanding Music and Lyrics. It was number 5 on The 100 Greatest Cartoons. Outstanding!
Unlike the Simpsons, the new episodes of the family guy still is highly entertaining and definetely funnier.

When I first saw the show Family Guy me and my family were really into it and entertained and said the show was hilarious. We enjoyed the crazy episodes and I really loved some of the jokes they had, but as the show progressed it got sour, the show started getting predictable, but then it started bashing God and Jesus and my family and I are a family of faith. We couldn't watch the show anymore because of the things, Seth Macfarlane said was very offensive. At first we gave it a chance and stayed open minded and tried not to judge it just by that, but the things the show kept on saying made me and my family uncomfortable. So I am writing this review to say that I would've enjoyed it, if only the bashing of not only my families beliefs, but also, other people's beliefs in a higher power wasn't thrown as jokes like that. All in all, I recently watched the show and an episode said God was autistic and that deeply offended me. So I would rather not watch the show or see it on TV.

Family Guy is amazing show. The storylines are hilarious and cynical as always. The characters are great, but need more character development to win back their fans. The writers seriously need to step up and fix some of the issues within the show's quality. Otherwise, it's still one of the many greatest cartoons of all time.

Family Guy started out on TV in 1999. But you know, I didn't really start watching it until, like, what, 2005? Well, I was 6 when I got to Edmonton in 1999, so don't be hating. Still, I wish I knew about it earlier. Seth MacFarlane is a really funny guy. He knows the events going on, and also, he has the guts to take a stab at ANYONE. No one is safe from him.Family Guy centers around the Griffin family: Peter, the father and mentally retarded man who works at the brewery (well, I think that's in later seasons); Lois, the mother (I don't know how to describe her); Meg, the eldest child and the one that everyone in the show hates; Chris, the eldest son who takes after his father--brains and physique, neither are good; Stewie, the baby genius who is trying to kill Lois in any way possible, and Brian, the family's martini-drinking dog who really fancies Lois (oh, he talks, too).Seth MacFarlane provides many voices in the show: Peter, Stewie, Brian (whose voice is the closest to MacFarlane's), Glen Quagmire (the sexually charged neighbour of the Griffins's), and others.Please be warned that this show is pretty offensive, and the characters really vary in a wide range (elderly pedophile, cop in a wheelchair {Joe}, Cleveland Brown {black friend of Peter}, etc.) If you give a s**t about anything that I'm writing here then try and watch this show. It's funny. Then say if this comment was helpful or not.

OK, what can be said about family guy? well first off, in first appearance the family may seem closely similar to the simpsons, but when you see peter, Louis,Chris,meg,Brian and Stewie in action you won't help but laugh. Now as a fan of both the simpsons and family guy I have to say that their similarities are mostly based on the characters traits: Peter Griffin a fat idiot who always get into trouble by doing something really retarded, similar to homer Simpson. Louis a housewife who is married to a total idiot but still stays with him for some reason, similar to Marge. Those similarities may have lead to people believing that the show is not original, but wasn't halloween(1978) similar to black Christmas (1974), besides the simpsons have been on the air for so long it's almost impossible to create a family such as this and not do anything the simpsons haven't already done, and though some jokes may appear similar to the simpsons' they will still have you laughing hard with them. Originality of films and TV shows are not based on the characters it's the storyline and what they have to offer that separates them from others that are similar to them, and I have to say with Peter's adventures you will easily see how original can Family Guy really be.

Just Give It A Chance. The show is good. Just take it for what it is worth. yes, sure there are a lot, and I mean a lot, of questionable antics that this show does. But do not compare it to The Simpsons. There is only on, and will always be on of The Simpsons.But the Family Guy is one of the unique shows that come out during the 98-99 season that does not copy other shows. This will cause a lot of attention for them. And a lot for the wrong reasons. It is like The Simpsons and the controversy it had when it first premiered.The baby, Stewie, is a character that will be a hit.The writing is original, controversial, but original.So please, just give this show a chance. We need more original shows like this on the air.

Family guy is a great show!!!!! I love it!!!!! Seth Macfarlane is a total genius. I salute you!! The thing I like about this show is that it's very funny. Obviously. But also what I like about it is when for example when Peter makes a mistake or something he goes into this professionally rehearsed (seemingly) speech and it really makes the show a lot better because the character learns from his mistake.Seth Macfarlane, I would like to thank you for all your hard work and dedication to make this show my favorite show on television. Cheers to you!!!!!!And to all you Family guy watchers out there, I thank you too for not letting this show to be canceled.And that is all I have to write about the best show on television, Family guy.

Brilliant, edgy comedy.Created by Seth MacFarlane (who also does some of the voices), a story revolving around Peter Griffin and his family - Lois, Chris, Meg and Brian, the dog - plus some friends and neighbours. Sort of The Simpsons but with more adult-orientated humour, more in- jokes and more pokes at modern life.Very funny and clever. Many of the jokes require you to know about history and other topics.Quite irreverent and edgy too - don't watch this if you're easily offended.Only negative is that Seth MacFarlane doesn't seem to know when to stop it. It is now into its 14th season and is feeling a bit jaded. Surprised that MacFarlane is continuing it, especially as he has already launched a few spin-offs (The Cleveland Show, American Dad).

Family Guy was Seth MacFarlane's foray into television almost 20 years ago. It's hard to believe that Family Guy is nearly that old already, even counting the years it was cancelled. It is amazing the show is still on tv, having been cancelled not once, but twice already. The audience loves the show, even though critics always compare the show to the success of The Simpsons.Peter Griffin, the patriarch of the show has done some crazy, miraculous stunts and it's surprising he's still alive. Stewie, the baby steals the show every chance he can. He and Brian, the family dog, have the best episodes and stories, especially the Road episodes, which center around parodying the Road to films of Bob Hope.The show is also full of songs and music, mostly originally written by MacFarlane and Walter Murphy. It's like having R rated versions of Randy Newman songs (which Newman has ironically been portrayed on the show as being mentally disabled). However, the songs are pretty funny and usually relevant.

"Family Guy" is probably the most ballsy sitcom ever produced. It relentlessly skewers everything it can think of, from TV shows to family drama. Best of all, it's one of the few TV shows on today that's actually funny.The show revolves around the Griffins: Peter, the obese father whose schemes are limited by his lack of intelligence. Lois, the mother who is more or less the head of the family, even though Peter considers himself to be that. Chris, the fat teenage son who has just as few brains as his dad. Meg, the black sheep of the family that is the but of everyone's jokes. Stewie, the baby who has plans for killing his mother and taking over the world. And Brian, the family dog, who is frequently the voice of reason, but is frequently corrupted."Family Guy" employs many tactics to get laughs from the audience. Most notable are the frequent cutaways that spoof what has just been said. They are effective because of the impeccable timing, and in how they play out. "Family Guy" uses spoofs to get humor as well, most commonly from 80's TV shows. What really makes the show so great is that a person doesn't have to be familiar with what it's spoofing. I'm sure it would help, but the material is funny enough in its own right. But the show doesn't stop there. Not only does it spoof just about everything, it skewers its own spoofs! The show is filled with off-color humor. The only reason why people aren't up in arms about the show is probably because it makes fun of every race, sex and other generality equally. There is nothing sacred here, and no one and nothing is immune from "Family Guy's" satirical jabs.Putting on musical numbers in a film takes a lot of time and effort, and it's a very big risk. But "Family Guy" contains some great songs. All well-written and performed, and of course they are hilarious (perhaps the most famous one, "The Freakin' FCC" is both catchy, and hysterical because it hits the ratings board where it hurts).The voice characterizations are right on the money. Seth McFarlane is tremendously talented. He provides the voices for Peter, Brian (which is his own natural voice), and Stewie. Not only are the voices consistent and creative, he can alter their pitch at will, so it really seems as if they are spoken by three different actors. Alex Borstein brings a nasally drawl to Lois that is perfect for the character. Seth Green is unrecognizable as Chris (had I not looked on IMDb, I would have never known that it was him). Lacey Chabert originated the character of Meg, and while she was good, Mila Kunis really elevated the character with her sharp voice. Kunis gives Meg a new, sharper edge that she didn't have with Chabert."Family Guy" has been compared to "The Simpsons," and that's entirely understandable (and not just because they are produced by FOX). Both are satires of blue-collar life, and while "The Simpsons" is good, "Family Guy" contains are sharper edge. The show is utterly fearless. There is no real sacred cow. The show lampoons handicaps (physical and mental), ethnicities, TV shows and movies, celebrities, politicians, religion (especially catholicism), drug use and addiction, sexual humor of all kinds (including S&M), and some that's just beyond description. Not everything "Family Guy" throws at the audience works, but as a whole, the show is consistently amusing and frequently hilarious.If there's any flaw with "Family Guy," it's that the jokes run on far too long sometimes. Particularly with the "awkward moment" jokes, the sequences are stretched for so long that not only does it cease to become funny, it becomes so irritating (and long) that a fast-forward button is warranted. These can be effective at about 10 to 15 seconds, but the show sometimes stretches these to beyond two minutes. One could argue that the show rewrites its rules to suit the plot, and it often does (for example, Brian frequently acts like a person, but he still acts like a dog when the story requires it). But that's not a problem because the show still works.Some people have argued that the show has stopped being funny. While I agree that it's not as edgy as it used to be, I think the blame lies with FOX, not McFarlane and his crew. The show originated with FOX, but after some lackluster ratings and viewer turnout, it was canceled. However, DVD sales were large enough for it to be picked up by Adult Swim. The show became an instant success, and it was once again bought by FOX. However, because the show is so big now, FOX is afraid to let the writers experiment and try new things. While it's still funny, the humor is not as fresh and edgy.Definitely check this show out. It's awesome.

This is the most insulting thing I've ever seen... AND I LOVE IT!!! There are those who say this is a rip off of the simpsons... well, granted there are similarities BUT(!) I would say that Family Guy takes what the simpsons do and MAKE IT BETTER!!! I just about wet myself with laughter when Quagmire shoots the simpsons!!! XD I agree with animalfanatic that Brian and Stewie are an excellent pair! The "Road To" episodes are the ones I enjoy most. The most recent one to cross my path was Road to Berlin and I have to say - I laughed my arse off!!! The best line was from the scene in the German U-Boat When Stewie says to Mort Goldman "I swear to God I'll stuff you in a torpedo tube and crush you against the sea!". Some of the lines in this series are amongst the funniest and most ingenious ever written!!! Seth McFarlane has my eternal thanks for this wonderful series!! 10 OUT OF 10

Usually I post reviews for MST3K movies, but this time I've decided to write about the animated television series Family Guy. To put it bluntly, this is one freakishly bizarre and hilarious show. Some of the jokes just have me rolling every time, like the Scooby Doo Mystery Files or the dialogue between the two news anchors that Peter watches. I would rather watch this than The Simpsons lately, just because I think that show has run its course and needs to be put to bed. Other Fox 'toons like King of the Hill and Futurama are pretty creative and funny in their own right, with King having a drier sense of humor then the wacked-out Futurama, but FG has characters that I just want to hug because they're so wonderful. Stewie is probably the best of the bunch, with Brian the dog coming in a close second. Peter and Louis are okay, although the show doesn't give them much to do besides yell at the other. Meg and her brother (can't think of his name at the moment) are usually left in the background, but having to pick I would say Meg is more interesting then her horny relation because she's just so boring and pathetic. In short, she's like every whiny teenager on this little marble of a planet. Family Guy should not be cancelled just because it cannot stand up against Friends or Survivor. Fox is being ridiculous if they think the little show can get good ratings when it goes up against the two biggest franchises in television at the moment and doesn't have any marketing on its home channel. They should move it to another night like Tuesday or Wednesday, because in my opinion there is nothing really good on Fox during those nights besides That 70's Show. In fact, cancel That 80's Show and give its time slot to FG, because 80's Show is just horrible. To end my review, here's my fave FG joke:News Anchor: Boy scouts selling cookies to little old ladies. Is there anything more arousing?News Anchor 2: I don't think so Bob.

When I first watched family guy I was wondering if I would like it I didn't I LOVED IT. It was hilarious. If you want to try watching it do.And they've added all seasons except the last one on Disney star, so the only reasonable thing to do was only subscribe and I've ever laughed so much I really recommend family guy.
When I First Watched The Show I Was Entertained You Must Teach Me How To Animate Like That Please I Would Be Happy

I really enjoy watching family guy. Its very original and very entertaining. Is definitely one of funniest animated shows of all time. Family guy is so much better than Simpson's. Simpson's is well passed its prime and family guy is still rolling. The newest seasons are very funny and great to watch. The first couple of season's was good but not that great. The animation was weak and is much worse than the newest season. I love all the jokes in this show, so many of them are funny and hilarious.There are always laughs when i watch this show (unless I've seen the same episode many times). All the characters are very unique and original. Stewie is my favorite character, he's hella funny. There nothing like the Simpson's...Family guy is better than the Simpson's because its more fun, funny and realistic. Simpson's is so fake, i mean c'mon..their skin is yellow, their head shapes and hair are weird and many characters have colored hair like blue, green, red..Family guy is so fun, i give this a 10/10 for nonstop entertainment and jokes

Jackie Gleason canceled the "Honeymooners" after one season because the "Classic 39" episodes would be difficult to top. And he was right. It's better to finish on a high rather than fade into mediocrity. The first 3 seasons of "Family Guy" were mostly brilliant. The next few seasons were more hit than miss. This most recent was awful: in one episode Peter became a pirate, which was absurd. Yes I know it's a cartoon, but at least have a reasonable plot. Even the Star Wars parody was more interesting than funny (I did like the fact that Rush Limbaugh was in it).This show is headed down the same path as The Simpsons, which hasn't been funny since the mid-90's. As a recent astute poster articulated, the older FG episodes were much funnier and at least had plots to them. It's the same with the Simpsons: it's no coincidence that the actors' favorite episodes occurred in the first 5 seasons. I bought the first 2 seasons on DVD and was listening to the commentary and Seth MacFarlane was mentioning Stewie's character evolvement. In the first few years, Stewie was the ego-maniacal but lovably erudite toddler bent on world domination. MacFarlane seemed to pooh-pooh that characterization, and now the writers are playing up Stewie's latent homosexuality. The homosexual thing has run its course. Was there anything funnier than when Stewie tried to control Chris to carry out Stewie's nefarious deeds--like when Chris went to the hardware store and Stewie was controlling Chris? Was there anything funnier than when Stewie was on Bill Cosby's show? Or when Peter was changing Stewie and sprinkled paprika on Stewie instead of powder? Or the Christmas episode?Speaking of ego-maniacal, Seth MacFarlane has certainly sold his soul to the devil. He got a boatload of money from Fox to produce absolute rubbish. The recent episodes do not come close to approaching the first 2 seasons, and yet people somehow find the more recent ones funny, and so MacFarlane just keeps lazily cranking out this tripe. Another thing I have noticed: in the first few seasons, the religious depictions were mildly irreverent and funny without being insulting (i.e the Pope in "Holy Crap" and the depiction of God and Jesus). Now in the last few years, McFarland's enmity towards the deity and Christianity has gone from cute and irreverent to outright blasphemous. And oh yeah, let's see if Obama is as lampooned as much as George Bush. Essentially, when the scripts suck, then go to plan B: insult Christians and embrace leftist politics. I read that many writers left after the 1st 2 seasons because the show was canceled. If they haven't gotten them back---then they really should because the show is more miss than hit these days. In fact, I don't even watch the first-run episodes anymore.The rating of 6 would have been higher if not for the last few seasons.

Seth is soft now, maybe he wants more Hollywood friends. I will keep watching, I still have hope. I keep the 7 stars for now lol.

Family Guy has to be my all time favorite cartoon.It is definitely the funniest TV show ever made and is better than The Simpsons.I have never laughed so hard at a TV show in my life The things that make the show so funny is the plot,characters and themes that are dealt with in the show.There are very few themes that have not been dealt with on Family Guy.I have seen just about every episode of Family Guy ever made and would have to say that the show was better in the first two seasons.My favorite characters are Peter because he is very funny and is the best character of the show.My second favorite character is Stewie because he is the funniest villain to be on a TV show.If you love Family Guiy you should check out American Dad because it is just so similar and is created by Seth McFarlane.I hope this show never ends because it is a comic genius! 10/10

Family Guy is an animated adult television series that features The Griffin Family including the parents Peter and Lois and their children Chris, Meg and Stewie as well as Brian, the family dog, who talks like a human and interacts like one. Peter is a blue-collar worker who has an endless amount of money for booze and parties. His wife Lois is a stay at home mom who teaches piano and comes from a very wealthy family of socialites. Meg is their teenage daughter who is not part of the in-crowd and faces ridicule from the family. Chris is a younger version of Peter, obese and not all there in the head. Stewie, their infant son, has an adult voice and is a super genius, able to build time machines and weapons. Family Guy has similarities to The Simpsons and was created by Seth MacFarlane. - Asif Zamir
Still funny but they're getting real risky with the jokes now lol.

I've watched numerous episodes of this series in the vain hope of figuring out what the hell it is that so many people love so much about it. No such luck. It just strikes me as 'The Simpsons' crossed with 'South Park' minus all traces of wit, irony, satire, and any other redeeming features of the aforementioned animated shows. The number of times I have laughed at this program I could count on one hand, and it's never been more than a mild chuckle.Look, I'm fine with repulsive characters, tasteless jokes, un-PC behaviour and gross-out humour - as long as there's actually some kind of point to it. But in 'The Family Guy' I have found none.And what is with all those pop-culture references, which are, again, used for zero effect? Oh, look, that bit they just did is like what happened in, umm, that movie. Err, hehe ... h ... hmm.I don't think I've given another movie or TV program a single solitary star here at IMDb, but I'm going to do so here - I just can't think of any other screen offering with so little to recommend it.
Simpsons or Family Guy? They're best that tv can give to you! (Maybe tpb also)

I saw "Family Guy" when it first aired on FOX in January 1999, and I couldn't stop laughing. The show was a riot. I loved it better than "The Simpsons".When it was cancelled a few years later, I went into depression's big time. I thought the world had ended for me. I wanted to see my buddy Peter Griffin to return for more "Family Guy". And sure enough, I later discovered on the Internet news it was gonna come back. The question that remained was: When was "Family Guy" returning to TV?I didn't have to wait long. Upon its return, I found it funnier than it was years before. The show had greatly improved all the way! The characters had developed to a better style. And the supporting cast had developed even better, too. The one who stood out was Quagmire. I just find him the raunchiest, but craziest fella in the history of cartoons. He makes Daffy Duck look like a loser.I've taped every show and remain a loyal fan to this day. I even work with some guys at my workplace who are fans of "Family Guy". What can I say, except this show is a downright, hair-raising heck of a series. I want it to stay on FOX until the day I die, then they can cancel "Family Guy"!

After like 2011 it was just dull humor that is just there to shock the audience
nothing was left of how family guy was.
i give it 6 stars because of the old days but i cant give it 9 stars as i would normally because these episodes are an insult to the cartoon medium

"Family Guy" spotlights the life of a Rhode Island family, the Griffins. Peter is a fat, stupid husband to Lois, who is smart and surprisingly tolerates Peter despite the various antics he does. They have three kids, angst-ridden Meg, dim-witted Chris, and Stewie, an intelligent baby with a demented plan of dominating the world (and killing Lois). Topping off the family is Brian, a talking dog who is somewhat the most normal one in the family.The early seasons of "Family Guy" were very funny, with random gags and some envelope-pushing humor along a good storyline. Now, the reason why I say the show is the most uneven comedy on TV because after it has returned to TV, it's very hit-or-miss. Story lines were kicked to the curb in place of pop-culture references and long jokes. There's nothing wrong with a comedy that's completely random, but it has to be funny all the way, or at least most of the time.The long jokes are mostly annoying, ruining the punchline by making it go on and on. If I was running the show, I'd fire the editor.The pop-culture references swing wildly between a funny joke or just a reference, which is unnecessary. Also, at times the show tries too hard to be offensive.The recent season so far is mostly funny, so I'm not complaining. However, Seth MacFarlane and his crew needs to let the funny outweigh the unfunny.

Well i do like Family guy, it does always make me laugh and i always enjoy watching it when nothing else is on at night. I don't think it is as good as The Simpsons but i still think it is good. It is so random and that is was sometimes makes it unique and fun to watch but i do think sometimes it is TOO random, i mean there is random and then there is going completely off the point.I think Family guy could be improved, maybe without having the random (real life) singers randomly appearing, i mean it is random enough without them scenes, they just make it stupid. I know a lot of people don't like this because of the randomness and swearing etc but that's how it is, it is always on late at night for a reason, it wouldn't be family guy without the swearing and random scenes etc.I think it deserves a 7 or 8 out of 10.

Family guy is often judge by its superficial appearance of being one-dimensional crap to lots of people who compare it the Simpsons elements, but the show itself has hidden depths of old and new personality traits of all the characters, however the writers should serialize the storylines into story arcs that last longer. The show's still great, but needs more fixing of the quality and animation formats.

For my 1000th review (on this account) I wanted to do something special, so I am finally reviewing that show of shows: Family Guy.You know, I used to be really into the Simpsons. Like, really into them. But everything I liked in them I got in greater quantities from FG. It wasn't a rip-off on the macro-level. They're both animated sitcom families but that's cosmetic at best. A lot of people insist that this show began well and then went to sea. The exact opposite is the truth. I think such people preferred the safe, ostensible rip-off because it was a more transgressive variation of that yellow family.It was after the show came back from the dead (twice) that the show realised it did not have to play it as safe and began to discover itself. Still transgressive and juvenile, but in a totally new way that no other show had dared to be.It's hard to put in words what this new generation of the Griffins was to me. So, I will use that catch-all word "postmodern". I mean it though; a show that rejects boundaries, a show that tips over sacred cows, a show that delighted in its own artificiality. FG tries to be a funhouse mirror image of society; it takes some of the most horrific and bizarre things that we have all gotten used to and tries to find humor in the darkest depths of the human soul.At one point the thing people hated was the interchangeable jokes. This is a very blinkered understanding of comedy. Family Guy cannot be evaluated under the lens of a conventional sitcom because it is not a conventional sitcom but rather a trailblazing hybrid of the sitcom and the sketch-show. They do whatever is funny no matter what. In addition to the intertextuality, the use of irony and self-reference, we have an unusual narrative structure that happily uses fragmentation and never mutilates its jokes by forcing them into a normal story-mode with a nauseating moral. On that note, I like to think of FG as a pastiche of that kind of sitcom where the "wholesomeness" is subverted into something, perhaps often quite vicious, but at the same time a lot more honest. They say the things that we are too scared to say.The cut-away gags are mostly pretty cool but the show also manages to maintain this efficient sketch-show approach to humor by showing scene after scene which are themselves just sketches with the main cast trying to do a particular thing, like Peter enjoying his obsession of the week or him helping his son to study better. In recent years they have been less cut-away dependent and actually have some really fun stories.You just get the feeling that anything can happen in FG. Including a lot of moments where the bizarre is juxtaposed to the mundane and people react (almost) you would expect them to, so the show really keeps you on your toes not only with surreal humor but also anti-humor and what I like to call anti-anti-humor (in which the humor is on how the bad the humor is...words don't really do it justice).A lot of people cannot take the heat with this show and condemn the main cast as monsters but that is the point. Yes, they embody the terribleness we see in ourselves and that is the point. I am the worst when it comes to condemning a show for punishing its characters but with FG, there is no pretence to the contrary. The show knows exactly what it is doing, it knows exactly what it looks like to you and you know they know that they are being brutal. There is a lot of authorial sadism in a lot of shows and I like to think that FG is just giving the audience a purer taste of the kind of thing they have grown addicted to. Yes, they treat Meg horribly. But Two and a Half Men treat Alan abominably too. With FG it is palatable because 1) like I said, you really feel that the writers are aware of what they are doing and 2) nothing is permanent in this show: the worst things can happen but by the next scene, it's fine.People object to the dark humor because people always will. It annoys me how FG gets singled out among all the other animated shows when it's no less clever. It's low brow but low brow does not mean easy to write. I like that they have no shame in jokes about rape, suicide, child-abuse etc. A joke on a thing is not that thing, ceci n'est pas une pipe. The show has always been written with a liberal bias. I'm not going to make excuses for this show when they have been blatantly racist or misogynistic or both but they have recognized this and are moving beyond that and not in the sanctimonious "we've had a lot of fun tonight BUT" way but simply in making great jokes on the right side of history. Once in while they have political episode and they do say a few things that need to be said but mostly it's just comedy rather than burdened with a heavy-handed point like South Park.No disrespect to South Park, but one observation: an idea that would fuel an entire episode of South Part is about a minute in FG.I think a lot of the louder hate for this show is just that too many people saw their worst self in it and couldn't quite handle it. Not that I don't respect why this show is not for everyone.Peter Griffin may indeed be Homer Simpson but more so. But the Homer is taken from Fred Flintstone who in turn is that Honeymooner's guy. He seems to have no standard upon himself and embodies toxic masculinity but, delightfully, he often shows he is in touch with his feminine side and loves discovering new hobbies. Lois used to annoy me as the most obnoxious high-horse character but she has since developed into a deeply troubled vision of the suburban "Mom"; a chemically dependent, well-meaning individual who really just taking what she can get from a wasted life, occasionally going the extra mile for her kids. I love how her marriage is not the classic sitcom idealism of Homer and Marge but something a lot more honest: a quiet desperation that she keeps doing just because it sort of works. I love how when Peter is shown a future where they have split up his response is "so I finally had the guts to leave her; good for you, Peter". This kind of subversion is part of why I adore this show.I am going to take this opportunity to list some things I don't like though.-Often too gross. Just because I like jokes about rape and suicide does not mean I enjoy anal flatulence.-Too often the joke is just an imitation of something from popular culture, not actually making fun of if including a long clip once.-Stretching things out so long it's funny is just not a good idea.-One time they drop a bunch of Game of Thrones spoilers. That's not OK.Moving on: I like Meg. I like how in recent years they have let her have her moments and in time she has gone from a victim to a really dark side. Sweet piece of ass too...I love Brian. He began as a straight man but they developed him into something amazing. He's a dog living in a human's world. He might be able to talk but that doesn't mean he is smart. He is a conscientious and literate person but he often thinks he is way smarter than what he really is: a wannabe intellectual trying to forge an identity. The double act with Stewie is so charming and poignant as they each try to take the other down a peg but are always there for each other. It hurts me when the writers seem committed to making Brian into a genuine villain but I like to think that villainy is contained to the episodes in question.I want to talk briefly about Quagmire: I think he is an homage to the classic '50s man. Considering he is based physically on Bob Hope and takes his voice from vintage ads and on top of this is a pilot (jet age), it's not too hard to see him as a way of making fun of a previous time in which people were less sex-positive but a lot more willing to look the other way on rape. This is perhaps why he is a shameless sex-hound. In later seasons it is fun to see his other side; someone snooty, hypocritical and with a lot of old-fashioned habits.I cannot not mention Herbert. Even having him for a character was audacious. Love him. There's no way British TV would make jokes like that. Peter is probably more like him than a lot of people realise.The design of the show is something admirable. A lot of sordid animated shows look filthy and use of country or hip-hop in the soundtrack. No disrespect to that aesthetic or musical genres but I love that FG embraced a more vibrant style reminiscent of retro musicals. It allows the dark/blue humor to juxtapose and not overwhelm. The musical numbers are almost always a treat that are sung well and superbly visualized. Tons of people have discovered new music from this show, I know at least someone became a big fan of Conway Twitty because of this show.This is hard to put into words but the writers really know their way around a joke even if you don't like the kind of joke. The timing is impeccable and the minute word choices (like especial instead of special) make a difference. In one episode Chris has a black lover and Lois, trying to break an awkward silence, says, "I voted for Obama once". First of all, it's racist to think that this would score points with every black person. But also, she says "once" so even if her voting history mattered here, it really counts for little. It is a self-defeating statement from every angle. Again, I'm not saying it's highbrow but it gives us so much to process and unpack in just five simple words.I can watch this again and again and it's one of the few shows that gets me laughing. For a while I dare say it got better ever season before just plateauing. In a world with so much nonsense and frustration, this show just lets loose and doesn't care about hurting feelings while still having the courtesy to not be a Nazi about anything. Maybe I'm being hypocritical but this is one of the most audacious works of art that humanity has yet come up with.
Family guy best comedy show ever its just perfect!

Family Guy is a long running animated program that has had an huge impact on pop culture. The show brought a nice mix of sitcom tropes, black comedy, "low-brow" humor, intelligent jokes, and gags. I've been watching since 2007, "Stewie Kills Lois" was my first episode, and I've been hooked ever since. However, the show has been running out of steam.I wasn't even around for the original run, but I think pre-cancellation episodes are superior to what we have now. They milked every opportunity for a joke they could. Nowadays, they just make lame observations or overdone celebrity comparisons, even when the plot screams absurdity. "Saturated Fat Guy" for example, had so many chances to play off of Peter's unhealthy habits, but it just fell flat. The scene where Peter thought about how successful his junk food business could be could've been home to some funny visuals, like him living in a mansion made of junk food, and diving in a pool of soda or beer. Instead, we got some line about a celebrity being sad on a ride. The jokes used to be clever, but recently, they over-explain them or give away the punchline in the delivery, which kills the momentum.Also, since Season 4, they've had scenes where the characters just stand around and talk about nothing for minutes on end. I think they're going for a "Seinfeld Conversation" kind of thing but it doesn't mesh well with the show's fast paced style. The show's use of black comedy has also downgraded. They're no punchline or point to the dark events on the show, they just happen and we're supposed to laugh. Just like a joke about a lamp can be lame, a joke about a dead baby can too. The pilot episode, for example, had a great joke about Hitler being jealous of a Jew at the gym. And for 1/3 of the show's run, Stewie would stop at nothing to kill his mother Lois, which was a goldmine of dark comedy. Nowadays, they do things like having Peter brutally slaying a whale for no good reason and blowing up children's hospitals just because. I will say the violence in the recent Quentin Tatrintino episode was great because it was a nice parody of his style. Also, they just list racial stereotypes now instead of playing with them like they use to.The show is still pretty good, but ironically, they lost their edge while trying to be edgier. The recent season seems to be getting back on the right track, especially with the story arcs and "experiment" episodes. Here's to many great FG episodes to come.

Very stupid show, with stupid and unlikeable characters. I just can't see why so many people like this show, it is easily one of the worst shows ever made, along with "Mystery Science Teather 3000" and "House M.D." What is so great about this stupid show? It was a complete waste of time, from beginning to end.The cultural references were lame, most of the jokes were unfunny and offensive, and all about this show sucked.This show is worthless. I only saw some episodes of this trash and I hated them.What happened with good, clean comedies like "El Chavo del Ocho"? This show is a dirty shame.

This show used to be amazing at everything, world building, comedy, characters, cut aways, and more, but now it's a washed up show that has most of the characters who used to be really funny confusing and hard to like. In my opinion the prime of this show was seasons 1-8 But it was still kinda going good till 9-12 But at season 13 was we're the episodes started to get boring. I'm still giving it a 9 though because of those golden episodes in seasons 1-8.

Well the latest TV fad is finally starting to slow down, but not fast enough. And it just keeps getting worse and worse.Do the writers have ADD or something? They can't go 5 seconds without breaking into some inane sequence that exists solely for a pop-culture reference, with no trace of subtlety."This is like the time when..." "Just like when..." "I haven't felt like this since..."Jeez! Give it a rest already! Why do they even bother trying to pretend that there's a plot? Why not just turn the whole thing into a sketch show?So is there anything original or innovative about Family Guy? No. It's trying to do what The Simpsons and South Park have already done, and it doesn't do it nearly as well. It's utterly forgettable. Years later when Matt Groening has become the modern day Hanna & Barbara, people will say "Seth MacFarlene who?"Another thing I don't get about Family Guy fans, other than their ability to withstand day after day of reruns of the same crap, is how they always use the argument when defending Family Guy "It was brought back from cancellation twice, so it must be good". There are things better than being brought back from cancellation twice, such as being brought back from cancellation once, or better yet, never being canceled at all.But whatever. Watch your crappy show. Enjoy it while it lasts. But when you come across the DVD sets selling for 2 bucks apiece at the old pawn shop, it will take you a few moments to remember that title "Family Guy".

Family Guy has become an institution of pop culture and American life in many ways, in the same way that it uses pop culture to make people laugh at old and silly nostalgic shows/references.I am glad they kept making it for a long time, though now I feel it has certainly seen its better years. Most seasons were a 8 or 9; the most recent season feels more like a 4 or 5. Like all great shows, this one is running out of gas, and feels like an amalgamation of disjointed writing on autopilot, with random scenes and jokes patched together to the point of absurdity. The other annoying part is the atheistic and political preaching that has become more apparent over the years. Usually, FG would do a good job of bashing all sides, but it has become a bit more aggressive and preachy on certain topics. MacFarlane is very talented, but it feels like they are running out of material, or let someone's nieces and nephews write the show now while the big wigs are out partying and doing other stuff. I still watch the show, and it has provided years of outrageous, non-PC entertainment, that so many of us still enjoy in America, amidst the suffocating tirade of socially-conscious, social justice, safe space crap from mainstream media, academia, and Hollywood of late.I can't believe people inflate the Simpsons as being better than this show, and accuse FG of ripping it off in every aspect. I barely see a connection, other than a funny animated family. FG is light years beyond the Simpson's boring crap, which has been on FOR FAR TOO LONG AND NO ONE EVEN REFERENCES OR CARES 2 CRAPS ABOUT ANYMORE!!!! SERIOUSLY!!! WHO WATCHES THE SIMPSONS OR BRINGS THEM UP AT WORK OR TO WATCH WITH FRIENDS???? They haven't been relevant in like 15 years. It blows my mind that half the negative reviews on here are worshiping at the altar of that dumb show, featuring yellow people with blue hair and pointy heads, that hasn't held my attention since day one.South Park and Fam. Guy are showing their age as well at this point, and the cut-away scenes and such are a bit overused in place of plot material or timely commentary, etc. but they are still some of the best comedy shows ever created.

It's funny how my brother only ever wants to see. Are the stupid cartoons that come on TV. This proves that comedy is easy. When people are watching comedy movies or a comedy TV series they are not thinking I better have some judgment about what I laugh at. No there are not. They are just thinking I want to laugh. Laughter feels good. Laughter is the very best medicine. And that is why comedy is so easy. IF comedy was hard this pieces of garbage would have been one of shortest running TV shows of all time. This show is not funny at all. It is just stupid and sick. Sick is not funny sick it just sick. This is a sick mean n.a.t.r.u.e.d pieces of junk. The people who you made it out be ashamed of them salves.

With all the excellent series FOX has unjustly *canceled* (Ally McBeal, Titus, Lone Gunmen, Quintuplets, Grounded For Life...), why bring back this one? It's not as good as the Simpsons, nor does it have the creative or the intellectual humor of Bart or Homer Simpson. Why does it insult and the viewer with inane plot points (in one episode, the father departs the plot to engage in violent attacks with a giant chicken for half the episode; the fight has nothing to do with the rest of the episode), but it also shows no respect for the persons or icons it is attacking. Example, this conversation between father and son: "Dad, what's a library?" "It's a place where the homeless go to wash and clean up." Stupidity isn't funny; it never has been. On the Simpsons, you can tell the writers respect and pay homage to what they are parodying (Marge's sister standing before a tank in Tienamen Square), but not on Family Guy. When Mel Gibson did the Simpsons, he was allowed to lampoon his Mad Max character and showcase his fondness for the Three Stooges. When Mel was featured on Family Guy, he was insultingly turned into a Biblical terrorist who hunts down the father and mother for stealing a celluloid movie. In another episode, the teenage daughter is forced to lose her virginity in front of a studio audience on Network TV. The football-headed infant on the show constantly conspires to kill his mother and take over the world, his older brother doesn't think and doesn't want to and the daughter seems normal till you realize how neurotic she is. The supporting characters are paper-thin entities without the depth of say Moe Syzlak, Ned Flanders, Clancy Wiggum or Seymour Skinner. The whole series occurs in a world devoid of logic or common sense and borders on a surreal insanity where no matter how stupid the father is, everything he says is somehow true. At least on The Simpsons, there is a rational pattern to the madness. But why does this idiotic series have a cult status? Despite being shallow and asinine, it is top notch animation and it doesn't make you think. It's irrelevant, it's insulting, it's nonsensical and it's only as funny as a fart joke. Why do people watch it? Probably out of morbid curiosity to find out how far down low it can sink trying to be funny or just because the remote control is on the television. It's still better than any episode of King of the Hill (a show that has been dragged WAY past its expiration date), but it will never reach the iconic status of The Simpsons.
It's a hilarious show, but one thing that I love from this show is that it is aware that it is a Simpsons spin-off ,that they rely on cutaways and pop culture references.. But they joke about it!!

This is a brilliant series along the same lines of Simpsons. Following a family as they go through life and problems etc. Slightly less realistic than Simpsons, talking baby and dog anyone? Family Guy goes where SImpsons or Futurama dares not, reaching past into the sicker jokes and more racy gags. And believe me, it works! Almost all the gags hit the mark and they'll have you in stitches(especially the random, frequent flashbacks!) When my brother first showed me this I wasn't hooked but after a few episodes I was hooked. You will be 2. 10/10 for a truly brilliant show. COngrats to Seth Macfarlane for bringing this show to life. :)

Despite the apparent structural similarity with The Simpsons - loud fat dad, housewifey mum, 3 children, a pet, typical suburban home, Family Guy is actually functionally and stylistically opposite to The Simpsons. Its avid use (and sometimes too much) of cutaway gags has been its main stay since the first season. While some hit the nail on the head (The Rhea Perlman and Danny Devito bit in Season 5 is spine-snappingly hilarious), others are less successful, coming across as contrived. And they can be annoying, especially when they don't advance the story line. (The Jesus bits are entirely unfunny and insulting)The chemistry between Stewie and Brian Griffin lends itself to pure comedy gold, so much so that Chris and Meg only manage to fulfill the role of the obligatory teenagers in your typical dysfunctional family.However, the feature film Stewie Griffin: The Untold Story, is MINDNUMBINGLY horrible. Thank goodness it went straight to DVD.Contrary to tiresome comparisons with the perennial Simpsons, Seth Macfarlane's approach with Family Guy is actually very different - it's much more politically incorrect, and amazingly, a lot more brazen.Creator of Ren and Stimpy, John Kricfalusi, famously criticized Family Guy for having "extremely low" graphic standards from a cartoonist's standpoint. I don't think it looks that bad though, the detailing and accuracy of some of the spoofs are quite successful.All in all, a great series to go with a great big bowl of chips smothered in ranch sauce and ass jokes.

The smartest show when it comes to comedy. if you watch this you can clearly see hundreds of references to amazing movies and tv shows. kind of like robot chicken when they used tons of jokes from classic tv shows. the favorite character as a kid was always peter.

I find the show either very funny, or too stupid. The show is a hit and miss with me. The too stupid humor I can usually see a mile away. Kick in the groin type of humor. The parody of pop culture humor is great. I love the Star Wars parody. I either watch the whole show or just pieces of an episode. When family guy hits a good rhythm the show is hilarious. I notice t v producers can get away with sicker humor with cartoons. I guess real life people are harder to get away with risky humor compared to animation. I give Family guy either a three or nine depending on the episode. That would give the show a six out of ten. Family guy is the modern day Simpsons.
The humor isn't clean and you'll definitely be offended if you're offended by South Park. Great for a laugh but you need to be able to not take yourself so seriously

Family Guy is an animated cartoon created by Seth MacFarlane and first aired in 1999. MacFarlane voices many of the Family Guy characters, though there are other voice actors. The daughter, Meg, is voiced by Mila Kunis, the older son, Chris, is voiced by Seth Green, and the mother, Lois, is voiced by Alex Borstein. In my opinion, MacFarlane has surprised me, and has proved himself to be wonderful at providing different voices. I was amazed when I found out how many voices he performed. To that, I give him two thumbs up.The show itself is funny at times. When I first saw it, I laughed at some of the randomness and crazy jokes. But lately, I've been thinking...is it really that funny? I have re-watched many episodes, and a lot of them are rather pointless, mainly season 4. Seasons 1-3 were the best at combining randomness with a good plot-line. It actually had some rather creative ideas, like the "big-ass pinata" for instance. I laughed at that. Season 4 overdoes it way too much, as well as other things.One of the problems I have with season 4 is its flashbacks and cutaways. Even more annoying is the "regular speech." It was funny for an episode or two, but they use it as a basis for its comedy, which is not a good thing. It seems that many episodes of season 4 have this now, and I have no clue how long it will last. In these situations, I usually am frustrated and desperate to move on.Another thing that has been done incorrectly is its overuse of slapstick. For season 4, that seems to be the basis of its comedy, which again, is a bad thing. The throwing up thing was mildly funny, but it lost its touch after about 5 or 10 seconds worth of throwing up. Okay, we get it, they're throwing up, it's funny, you don't need to show us anymore, we get the point! Finally, another thing I am absolutely tired of is all the "Meg bashing." Seriously, what did she ever do to get picked on so much? I mean, she might not supposed to be popular, but it's even worse to be picked on. A lot of Family Guy fans will criticize me for having this opinion and rebuttal by saying it's funny. To me, it's not funny. It is tasteless and lacking in any point. Do people really think it's funny to pick on someone that hasn't done anything wrong? I don't, and there's nothing funny about that. I mean seriously, where's the humor? What's supposed funny about it? I think she is cute and should get revenge in season 5.Something else to consider about this show is Seth MacFarlane himself. He has been criticized by many, and he often takes jokes too far. The Elizabeth Smart joke was not funny and just horrible.This show is good, but I think it should clean up its act and make improvements here and there. Would I recommend viewing it? I would recommend seasons 1-3 and maybe some episodes of season 4. But some of the last episodes, Petergeist and Untitled Griffin Family History, are among THE WORST Family Guy episodes EVER, so I would not recommend those.

......is that they finally realized what a piece of crap this show was and took it off the air.  Family Guy is one of the worst cartoons to come out. Peter Griffin is just a jerk.  He doesn't care for anyone but himself.  He is supposed to be a "clone" of Homer Simpson(which was made fun of in a recent Simpsons Halloween special), but what the writers ignored was Homer, though rude and selfish most of the time, actually does feel remorse and regret at times(he even once actually tried to improve his family from being the slobs they were!), but that part was ignored when Peter here was created.  Like I said, he is thoughtless, uncaring, and selfish, and only looks out for himself.  The episodes are pointless, with scenes that are supposed to be humorous, but are either boring or just plain stupid.  The stories are also extremely offensive, not South Park offensive, but offensive enough to be really crude, vile, and tasteless.  Ignore this "comedy," and watch an old episode of the Simpsons instead.BOTTOM LINE:  I'll start laughing all right.... the day Peter Griffin gets what he deserves.
