If you thought that the Simpson were dysfunctional. As they were the first dysfunctional family in the cartoon sense. But they are cakewalks compared to this family.As Stewie is the one that causes all the destruction. He may be a baby. But he is British and he is smart. Plus he has such a sharp tongue along the way.Brian the dog is the perfect straight man to Stewie's antics. While Peter Griffith is a bumbling blue collar worker. As his wife Lois is the perfect straight man or woman, for him as she is from a wealthy family.There is teenage daughter Meg who is awkward but pretty bright and Chris in addition to Stewie, the younger version of Peter. Not too bright and a slacker.Still though Seth McFarland who provided the voices and is the executive producer and creator of the show, took the Simpsons to a whole new level.

For those unfamiliar with Family Guy, this was an animated series that for a while, aired on Fox before being yanked. It has since made a successful comeback (and its second series premiere did so with a nice slap in the face to Fox executives by listing all of the short-lived b-grade and c-grade series that would come and go before Family Guy was permitted another shot). And it was quite different from previous Fox animated fare (i.e. The Simpsons and King of the Hill) because of it's characters and purpose. The Griffith family, at the center of this series, is comprised of the typical sitcom-esquire idiot (and nowadays, crude and insensitive) father figure, Peter; his stereotypically (sometimes) level-headed wife, Lois; the clueless teen daughter, Meg; their half-retarded son, Chris (see the Sept. 2005 spoof on Family Guy); their insolent British-accented toddler, Stewie (probably one of the funniest characters on the show); and their hinted-to-be-gay talking dog, Brian. (These characters are basically repeated for "American Dad").I've never been a tremendous fan of "Family Guy" because its humor is based purely on trying to outdo its own outrageousness (and in even more of an offensive and outrageous manner with the on-again/off-again series "American Dad"). True, there are some awesomely off-beat moments which are just so weird, you can't help but to laugh (particularly from many of Stewie and Brian's strange adventures).And where have we seen this before? With South Park, which Family Guy creators are either trying to make a comparable model of (and you still have limits since it is aired on network television---but of course, there are always the DVD collections). Either that, or they are trying to top what South Park has managed to (and continues to) successfully do (and again, Family Guy has to adhere to certain limits that Comedy Central programming does not). But, with South Park, it wasn't always simply outrageousness for the sake of being vile or disgusting or offensive or whatever, but rather, it is comic material ancillary to often wildly excellent satire. Something which Family Guy radically lacks and, is therefore, repetitive and tiresome in it's attempts to be outrageous for the sake of outrageousness. After a while, you can only get so extreme and then the humor is just dead. (Even some of the antics of South Park are no longer shocking enough to be funny anymore).

Let's face it. Whether you like it or not, Family Guy was once a good show. The cutaways were funny, the plots were funny, and the overall show was just..funny. But then it wasn't, as the show decreased in humor and focused on ratings trap episodes and just bland and boring plots. It fell from grace, but let's all remember how it was once good. Once.

i have 1 word....  FAMILY GUY IS THA BEST! with jokes as: well if my son, cant come in your club, i will go bymyself, see ya later chris! i mean thats comedy. and i think its better than simpsons and futurerama as well. i mean a family with a dog that speaks, and everyone understands him. and a baby that speaks, no one understands him exept the dog, and they have some big conversations, because they are also the smartest of the whole family. aint that comedy or WHAT?!?!

OK...I know this has been said a million times, but to add insult to injury...the show has gotten really stale lately. Particularly, I wanted to point out, that at first it was about a man trying to find a job to support his dysfunctional family, or impress them, or be a decent person around them. Something like that, it was about the family and how the man would deal with an issue involving said family. Lately though, and by lately, I don't literally mean lately, more or less after the 3rd or 4th season, Peter's lost his character traits entirely and become more or less a doll that spews retarded jokes. It still tries to make reference to it's past episodes and events that have occurred, but you don't even care, because his character isn't even a character anymore. Stewie's become gay, which would be perfectly fine if they didn't make him hit on EVERY SINGLE guy in the show. Also, because he's gay he had to be a trannie? What? Him being a trannie wasn't funny the first time I saw it, why drag it on, not just for the one episode, but onto LATER episodes. Hell, South Park delved in Cartman being gay, but they didn't make it his ENTIRE character. He still is the crazy guy who does very creepy things, though still very childish.The show also always complains that Meg isn't an interesting character. Well, when you don't write her to be interesting, she won't. It's pretty logical that if you don't involve a character in the show, you might as well kill her off. Of course they can't do that, and have killed off other unimportant characters, the point remains, they could get rid of Meg somehow, but no, they want the stupid one-line jokes that involve her getting hurt, whether hurt feelings or actually physically hurt.There's also what I call "filler" moments, when the crew can't write anything interesting enough to fill a whole episode and just have something else take over, or drag out something where animation is so simplistic that everything stays in one place and only a mouth moves. For those who know, they can just draw a simple figure of the character, and put the mouth even more in the foreground, it's lazily done. "MOM MOM MOM" OK...Filler moment. The random flashbacks, I honestly can't complain about. It was part of the show when I liked the show, and it should remain part of the show...it's when they turn into filler moments that I really hate. "Mr. Conway Twitty, let's hear a whole song from you now to divert the attention from the fact that Seth and the other writers couldn't come up with the 5-10 minutes of that song" What's worse is, they just take a video of Conway Twitty, they don't even BOTHER animating a scene of it. No one laughs at it, I end up turning the channel if I don't get bored before that moment anyway. The only filler I've liked so far was short and to the point, with "The Rock" simulating Peter and Lois having sex. The actual episode beyond that wasn't all that funny...however...Beyond all the complaint, there must be something to draw me in, because I do keep watching it enough to know all this. Maybe it's hope...but maybe, just maybe, it does still have entertainment value to me.

Family Guy <> Simpsons. Family Guy >= South Park. I been a fan of The Simpsons since day 1 just when I a kid and grew up on The Simpsons. I lived through Bartmania. When The Simpsons went popular in early '90's, all the other channels tried to jump on and failed miserably. Then in '95, a cult cartoon became a national phenom with South Park, and I also became an immediate fan. Lastly in '99, right after the Superbowl I became a fan of a new series called Family Guy. While the animation is nowhere as good as The Simpsons but not as crude as South Park, it is not comparable to The Simpsons. The dialogue & jokes seem to definitely be more South Park influenced than The Simpsons. At times, Family Guy pushes the envelope a lot more often than South Park (movie & series).The first season was tamed compared to the 2nd and now finally the 3rd season. Family Guy has become a cult hit even after it was pulled off the air in mid-2000. I tend to find Family Guy to be way more offensive with its jokes than South Park. Its unbelievable the amount of sexual innuendoes and no-hold barred dark humor on just about every subject possible to be offensive on has been poked at in this series and this is aired on a public channel. Cable can be a bit more lenient, but just watching this series on Fox I'm just utterly amazed what it gets away with. While it's tame on the cursing, the humor goes to the absolute absurd. One particular example is when the character Meg is talking to guy, and to keep his attention she blurts out, "Well I can't taste salt." While younger kids who watch this show won't some jokes, adults should be able to pick it up quickly and will just have you rolling on the floor laughing. Actual actors could never do the material on this show. That's what makes it brilliant since its not done by actual actors it allows the extremely creative writers to find things to poke at. This show it tailored for 18-34 male audience with frequent pop culture references from 70's-90's but seems also to have racy humor that I don't think women would find to be humorous.The last several years of The Simpsons have not been great and at times down right weird and South Park has been hit & miss with each particular episode in the last 2 seaons and they seem to be missing the original formula. This can not be said about Family Guy as it just keeps improving with each episode. If you like your humor very dark with no sugar or cream, this is a series you just can't miss.

The reason that this show is so popular can be summed up in one sentence; People are dumb.This show is written by people who are racist, cheauvenist, and immature, but smart enough to realize how many men have low intellects, and how to aim this show right at them. It's psychologically similar to showing videos of bananas to chimps. You get a positive reaction.Now, I say this is aimed at men because I have yet to meet any woman who likes this show. They may tolerate it for their husbands' sake, maybe even crack a smile or two. Read the comments list....I found only one comment that was apparently written by a woman, and her attitude was not in favor of the show. It's like that other garbage called "The Man Show," it's written for dumb men to enjoy.First off, the father is not someone who could function in everyday life without several medications and constant supervision (and I must note that I am very tired of any sitcom that dummies down all the men to babbling idiots, though I am sure that some exist, but leave them off the television.) Peter treats his wife like crap. He talks down to her, treats her like a slave, cares little or nothing about how she feels, or her opinions. He has views on women that were common in the 1930's. I've seen him beating her up, ordering her to fix him something to eat, telling her that she can't drive a car because it's illegal for women to drive. He watches Lifetime television, lovingly called "Television for idiots." The writers cleverly pointed out there that women were idiots. He is also racist, but it's OK, because he needs a Jew for only for financial gain. Oh boy, that's funny. Ha ha ha. Now I understand about his singing for "those good old fashioned values." Old fashioned as in decades ago.Lois is not any better. True, she has some intelligence, but not enough to leave the jerk. But she loves him for who he is. Ahhh, sigh. Get real. She's the dream girl for every dumb man in America; she cooks, cleans, puts out, and puts up with your stupid ass mistakes. The children don't hold any better, as the oldest boy is a clone of his father, and the daughter is self pre-occupied (ok, most teen girls are, I'll give you that). The baby is just a rip off of another big-headed character. I won't say who, but Stewie should have a twin that says "Narf!" The show is pure garbage. Unlike dysfunctional family shows like The Simpsons and Married with Children, this show lacks any real charm. It's aimed at the lowest common denominator amongst TV viewers, and has no redeeming values at all. Fox made a great move in canceling this show, but because idiots also have a voice, it's making a comeback. I'm half convinced that every guy that likes this show lives in a trailer park, but there aren't that many trailer parks in existence to warrant all of the votes received to bring back the show. That is a truly scary thought.Criticize my thoughts if you like. But if you really like this show, you probably didn't understand half of what I said, did you?

Family Guy is a very divisive show. It divides people into groups that like and and might not be total idiots, and people who hate it and most assuredly are.In a time when almost every mainstream animated comedy has lost its way, either spiraling downward into clichéd irrelevancy like "The Simpsons" or destroying itself with wholesale arrogance and self indulgence like South Park, it is nice to see that SOMEONE understands that the purpose of a comedy is not to keep a long dead franchise going for merchandising rights, or to act as the creator's own private blog, but to be funny.Family guy is a show that is unafraid to take risks, to do new things, and change the formula between episodes almost every week, instead of just on Halloween or Xmas. In short it's what the simpsons was in is golden years, but less formulaic. It may not be quite as sharp, and it's highly British sense of humor may be lost on some, but it still remains one of the few oasis in the massive comedic dry spell that is animated television.

Family Guy is what it is, dick-fart jokes at its purest. If you are into that type of thing, then you will love this show...however, it fails completely on every other level if you don't like that style of humor. The overall quality of the show is rather low in my opinion, both writing and direction. By which I mean, the show is just so easy to predict the punchlines and it is rarely even amusing. If me and my friends watch, we spend the time saying the punchline before the setup is even done or we figure out better punchlines. And then there is the whole style of cutting away from the story to go do some little side joke, thats an OK form of directing/writing...but its still weak.But yeah, you either like it for the humor or you hate it for the simple humor (and its anti-intellectual sense of pride)

What can I say about this show? Of the 50 episodes that I have seen I have not really enjoyed two of them, the second Death episode and Peter's Father episode. I recognize that this show is not for everyone, the absurdist humour, the Kool-Aid man breaking through the courtroom wall, the unPC elements, "Don't kill strippers they are already dead inside.", and the racial slurs, "Day in the life of an Irish wo/man".  But if you want something that isn't afraid to use shock in its humour, that doesn't mind being surreal, check it out on DVD, and look for it on TV in 2004, as I hear there will be another season.

I love Family Guy I've watched it since I was a kid it has something about it that makes it extremely enjoyable this show gives a lot and is always talking about hot button issues which can get a little annoying if it's not handled tastefully but more times than not it is and that's why Seth MacFarlane is a comedic genius. His comedy is definitely not for the faint of heart but if you give this show a chance and like it, check out his recent movies ( Ted, Ted2, A Million Ways to Die in the West)

For me, this is truly a very good show. I know some people get annoyed at the regular cutaways, myself included (some of them being simply unfunny, or sometimes its just the fact I don't have the contextual knowledge to understand the joke, I'm 15) , but in reality , most of them are very good. It is well animated and nice to watch, but the thing I love most about it is the diversity of the episodes. The Brian and Stewie episodes are absolutely excellent, for example the "Road to" episodes and other time travel episodes, not to mention other episodes like "Three Kings". These episodes are such fun to watch, especially when you're my age. The risky humour and ridiculous gags make me laugh out loud at times, something I don't usually do at the TV. Since I began watching a few years ago, I've bought 8 seasons, and just watch them whenever I'm not feeling so good. Seriously a great show, even if sometimes the cutaways are infuriating.

Family Guy is pure genius comedy! I love this show. I starting watching early 2005. I didn't know what I was missing. This show is way better then The Simpsons! You just got to love Peter. He is such a stupid moron who is always getting himself into something. With this show they can have something that has nothing to do with what their talking about and just throw it in there and it'll be funny like throwing Vinny from My Cousin Vinny in the middle of that island with those foreigners. Has nothing to do with it and it was so freaking funny! That is what I love about this show, small witty little gags like that that you just keep laughing about forever.

SPOILERS For the first time ever, 2004 was the year a television series was resurrected due to DVD sales. That programme was hilarious cartoon "Family Guy". Full of cult references and hilarious one liners, this series has thrived on a student cult following and is perhaps more popular now than ever before.Peter Griffin (voiced by creator Seth MacFarlane) is the father of the Griffin family. A loud, often offencive man, the only thing as big as Peter's stomach is his love for his family.Peter's wife Lois (voiced by Alex Borstein) is a passionate redhead with a rich background. Lois is devoted to Peter and despite all his idiotic ideas, she stands by him.The beauty of "Family Guy" is it's relevance to modern humour. Whether it's jokes will remain fresh is unknown, but at the present time it remains hilarious, even after multiple viewings.Perhaps the finest part of "Family Guy" is the relationship between baby Stuie and dog Brian (both MacFarlane). Stuie is an intellectual with designs on world domination whilst Brian is an alcoholic who far too often is led astray by best friend Peter. These two characters, whilst completely random, are superb because they provide an air of intellectualism to balance out with Peter's stupidity.In general, the great thing about "Family Guy" is how much of an ironic cult programme it is. Cult programmes tend to be programmes which small numbers watch and will regularly quote from. Evolving from this original scenario, "Family Guy" is now a programme practically every person on the planet has seen at least five minutes of. Still, whilst never award winning and not as well known as cartoons like "The Simpsons", everybody still quotes the Griffin family at regular intervals.As an animation, "Family Guy" is one of the finest. With guest voices like former Batman Adam West, the series has regained it's popularity in recent years due to a strong student following. This is a well deserved following since "Family Guy" is perhaps one of the funniest comedies in recent years. If you haven't seen the adventures of the Griffin family, then go out and find a DVD today. This is one family you won't want to miss.

Hi All..I'm a lil'ol English fan and have just found out that Fox have cancelled the show.... Why ??....I mean i'm really interested.... Is it that it's starting to get funnier than the Simpsons..(can't have that now can we ...) I mean...don't get me wrong...the Simpsons is legendary and an all round cracking watch...but its no longer quite as sharp as it was, whereas family guy...coarse as it may be..keeps you sitting on the edge of your seat to make sure you see every tangent / irreverent gag ...C'mon fox....bring it back...you know you want to...

When Family guy debuted in 99, I was one of its biggest and most loyal fans. It was fresh, funny and the writing was crisp, clean, and pushed the envelope without being totally offensive. I enjoyed the show immensely for the first few seasons. However, it has gone completely south in the last four yrs. They are completely out of ideas and continue rehashing these stupid 1980s references and stereotypes. Half the audience wasn't even born before 1990. I'm 35, so I know where the references are from, but they still aren't funny. For instance, the cutaway in the most recent episode of the pair from the Facts of Life shaking her ass in strip club while the guys watch and she says "girls girls girls" totally not funny. The last episode was so appallingly disgusting, crude, and demeaning.Quagmire's musical number Sunday was X-rated. It was one of the most despicable scenes ever. Is Seth and his ultra leftist crew the only ones who find this funny? I hate G. Bush too, but I don't need this idiot shoving his hatred of "W" down my throat every chance he gets. Also, he takes totally demeaning shots at Republicans like when he spoofed Rush and J McCain. In the early years, the show was hilarious.And, even if Peter was an idiot, he was a lovable one as was Lois. Both of them are unbearable to listen to now. I used to love her character. she was risqué yet had a motherly nurturing personality. Now, she's just crude, demeans meg for no reason, and has a potty mouth. she used to support peter in the early episodes now she's just damn annoying. I cant stand Chris and Meg. His lines suck and her personality is awful. She used to be a lovable, amiable nerd who was constantly put down by her peers. I always found Chris horrible. he adds nothing to the show. Stewie was evil and compelling with his passion toward killing his mother.I loved how evil yet funny he was. Now, he's just gay and annoying. Its like they are trying to push his homosexuality rather than what his character was.Also, I used to love Quagmire but now the writers barely use him. He's given maybe one line per show ( a perverse one at that) and that's it. He's one of the best characters. Why they don't utilize him more effectively is beyond my comprehension. The secondary characters- Joe, Cleveland, tom tucker, Diane, really don't add anything to the plot or story. Why was Cleveland granted his own show? he sucks. he's so boring to listen to. I never liked him. Same with Joe. he yells so loud, is a meat head, and he's a cop- definitely don't like them either.In my opinion, they need to produce one excellent final episode then end the series.IF they don't, I won't watch again. These last few new episodes were extremely boring, uncreative, and totally offensive. The comedy isn't fresh anymore-simply degrading toward minorities, handicap, republicans, Catholics, etc. Seth, I don't need you shoving your political ideology down my throat. Seth your a talented fellow. You need to retrace the steps that initially made the series fun and fresh.Now, your just rehashing old stale material, overusing these stupid ridiculous irrelevant 80s cutaways, resorting to barf humor, degrading people etc. Seth you can sing, draw, and make people laugh. Do it in a classy , reverent manner. I wont watch another episode after what I saw Sunday. you need to end the series now. IT is dragging, boring, and you and your staff seem completely exhausted ideas.I mainly watch the show for Stewie, Brian, and the q man. Brian's dialogue used to be awesome. he's also underused. Also, he's just a pompous drunk idiot now too. It's really sad. This show has amazing potential had the writers stuck w/what worked for them at the end of the century. IF you can't recapture that spirit and energy, end the series now. I'm one of those fans who keep hoping that "this next episode will be a great one."Then, after watching this disgusting display, I turn the TV off disappointed that I wasted the last 30 minutes of my life and this crap.These cutaways now are so boring and stupid. Why does Consuela appear in every episode? They did a skit about the sport of curling, and she was sweeping the ice as the puck rolled. Totally dumb and not funny. And, when Quagmire fired the puck into that Canadian strippers pussy during that musical number Sunday, was the last straw for me. That was an x-rated skit. I might see it posted on you porn. IT was that gross. I'm not a prude or gay. But, I don't like senseless degradation of women for no reason. Seth, retire the series now. Do family guy fans a favor. It's a far cry from what it used to be. American Dad is much better. They should be equally good. End it now Seth-this is totally reprehensible. Just throwing sexual, gross jokes for no apparent reason isn't comedic or entertaining. It's just simply sad. You can do better. do one climactic episode and end on a high note. Also, your New Englanders, why did you never spoof "cheers?" that would be a great skit. peter as same, Brian as norm, Lois as Diane. that would be mad funny if done well. again give it up Seth. move on with your other professional ventures. good luck to you from a former family guy fanatic---Ken

Family Guy was a funny and hilarious show, but now it's an unfunny and repetitive mess which is a disgrace to its former self.Old Family Guy 8/10
Present-day Family Guy 2/10.

The show, which played out like one one-liner after another has the potential to be a breakout hit.  Unfortunately it has to suffer the burden of being "the next Simpsons", or harder still to be "the next South Park". I think this show has a lot to offer to network television, but it's in a league of it's own.  The best animated show to hit television in  few years, with enough intelligence to endure for a long time.  My only advice would be to hold back some of the one-liners. The show, "Family Guy" is a cartoon on Fox television and Adult Swim. The show is about a guy that puts the "Fat" in father. The family is made up of a stupid and fat dad who falls down for now apparent reason and every time he recalls something of the past there is a hilarious flash back. There is a mom, Lois that can get annoyed with Peter, the dad but still obviously loves him to much to be mad at him for more than 10 minutes and is looking for something more in life then just being a stay at home mom the it almost murdered by her son, Stewie every episode. The son, Chris who adopted his father's jeans of stupidity and who has a monkey in his closet that supposedly was once a good monkey that turned evil when he found his monkey wife cheating on him with another monkey. Now the monkey almost every episode points and glares at Chris when nobody is looking. The daughter, Meg is very self conscious and is probably the least popular girl in her school just because of her glasses, her undersigned purse, and her unfashionable clothes. She is also admired by a red haired, geeky, creepy, boy who has tried to put moves on her numerous times. The dog, Brian who can speak and walk on two legs resembles, Snoopy from the old cartoon, Peanuts who is Charlie Browns dog. He is also probably the smartest thing in the Griffin house. This show in my point of view is more clever and more hilarious then Simpsons and South Park put together even though I love South Park.

This show is funny at many times but the humor is at the same time, plan and stupid. You are always going into flashbacks or dreams of Peter's. The Simpsons is a better show.And by the way this IS a rip off of The Simpsons everyone. A nagging wife, a perverted father(usually the start of the problems and pretty much the main character), a fat-ass,dumb-ass son, a sister that is a very big nerd and tries to fit in, a baby(if there is another thing funny about this show it is Stewie, he is the best and the only reason to watch this), a crazy neighbor(Simpsons its Flanders the Christian, Family Guy is Quagmire the perv.), and finally a family pet(even though he does talk, walk, and drink).I still like Family Guy and you do get A FEW laughs from time to time but it doesn't beat the classic Simpsons. And I'm sorry to break all you Family Guys maniacs out there but I'm pretty sure it will be canceled in about 3-5 more years but The Simpsons have been on for about 20 years.Family Guy is an O.K show but will NEVER beat The Simpsons.

This show is the only show I know to routinely mock its viewers. The characters devolve instead of evolving, over the course of the show, they get progressively worse and worse becoming more and more unbearable. The writers have made an episode about every sick and evil thing you can think of, this show feels satanic at times. "Family Guy" has given countless viewers loads of laughs! The show has enthralled me since it first aired in January of 1999. The simple fact that this is only one of two animated shows (alongside "Futurama") resurrected by the fans after it was initially cancelled in 2002 pays testament to the fact that this show is hysterical! Too often, "Family Guy" is pushed aside as a plagiarism of "The Simpsons," and that its humor is annoying since many of the jokes are tangents which have no relevance to the plot. The counterargument I present to the accusation of plagiarism involves a "Simpsons" episode. In "Treehouse of Horror VII: The Genesis Tub," it can clearly be seen that the Simpsons is plagiarizing a "Twilight Zone" episode called "The Little People." This isn't the only instance of "Twilight Zone" references in "The Simpsons Treehouse of Horror," but it was highlighted by a "South Park" episode called "The Simpsons Already Did It." Which brings me to my next counterargument about the humor of "Family Guy." To quote Mr. Seth MacFarlane (the creator of "Family Guy") when he spoke at the Harvard Class Day Speech in 2006: "The boys at 'South Park' are absolutely correct. Those cutaways and flashbacks have nothing to do with the story. They're just there to be funny. That is a shallow indulgence that 'South Park' is quite above, and for that I salute them." This is an accurate observation considering how the quality of "South Park" episodes has declined recently. Just relax and learn how to enjoy a joke, however it is delivered. It doesn't matter what the joke is, but what counts is how you construct it! These tangents the show often utilizes are creative and laugh-out-loud funny! I find myself often out of air from the irreverent jokes and unique style in which they are presented.In short, "Family Guy" gets written off too often by critics and viewers alike. While the tangents which have no relevance to the plot are the most famous (the 'Giant Chicken' gag comes to mind), "Family Guy" often times uses the same kind of toilet humor as found in "South Park." The simple fact is that this show garners such a loyal fan base that it was brought back from the proverbial grave by DVD sales shows that this show is here to stay and deserves recognition as one of the best, if not the best program on television today.

The first few seasons of family guy were simply amazing. Great wacky stories and off-beat jokes that related to the plot. When I watch these old episodes I have to think to myself "why did they mess with perfection?" When I think back to the pilot, which was my personal favorite, the show actually had a plot and the random jokes were kept to about 3-5 minutes.Since Family Guy was brought back the show has obviously changed writers with Alex Borstein being the head of staff for writing, which has seriously damaged the show. Now the jokes are all the same, they are either an obscure pop culture reference or are just a long running joke such as the "mummy mom mom mum mummy" joke by Stewie which is just that quote said over and over again for 2 minutes. Also these jokes have nothing to do with the plot anymore, they introduce the joke by saying "this is more ______ than when "character" did _________" For example Peter is shocked to find out he is fat at the doctor and says "This is more awkward than having sex with a rhinoceros that doesn't love you anymore." To me this is just lazy writing with a joke that could be used in any situation and has absolutely nothing to do with the plot. The joke was not even funny.Following that the show has become more "edgey" for no good reason with more sex, religious, and historical references that are just put in to offend and shock the viewer rather than make him/her laugh. The show used to be "edgey" but was in the right context and had proper timing to make the joke work. When I see Stewie graphically beating up Brian for 5 minutes of an episode I am not entertained or amused.Family guy was a great show, but now the show is declining in quality very quickly and its only been 5 seasons or so. The Simpsons didn't drop off until about season 10.

The success of "Family Guy" is further proof, as if any was needed, that quality is not always rewarded and bad work often meets with success. Seth MacFarlane, a polymath of no particular distinction (he does everything, but badly), created a show composed of various ripoffs: Stewie is a ripoff of the Brain from "Pinky and the Brain," Meg is basically Daria, Chris is Ajax from "Duckman," Peter is equal parts Archie Bunker and Homer Simpson.The show is second-rate in every way: bad writing, bad animation, bad voice acting (Seth MacFarlane does many voices, but they're all monotonous and indifferently acted), bad stories, bad characters. The so-called "jokes" are just references to various TV shows, movies and commercials; real comedy writing requires some characterization or a satirical gloss on what is being referred to, but Family Guy presents everything in dumbed-down form: it's a cultural reference, or a sex joke, therefore it must be funny There were some good episodes, mostly toward the end of the most recent season, but basically it's a not-very-good show for youngish viewers who think that a penis joke is "cutting edge." And that's the point: Family Guy is not very popular with people over, say, 30 -- hence its failure on Fox (and the show got terrible ratings everywhere Fox put it, except the indestructible post-Simpsons slot). But it has succeeded based on its appeal to teenagers and twentysomethings; it is, as someone said, a kiddie show for older kids, crummy comedy for frat-boys, about as cutting-edge as a Bob Hope special.The comparison has been made to "geezer TV," in that some bad shows succeed because they appeal to elderly viewers -- Family Guy is a bad show that succeeds on the basis of pushing all the right buttons for twentysomething viewers. But at least Diagnosis Murder was fairly well written. Family Guy is considerably worse than any episode of "Murder She Wrote." So next time you scoff at your grandmother for liking the Lawrence Welk Show, desist, and scoff at your college-age cousin for liking "Family Guy," one of the worst shows ever made.

I didn't want to like Family Guy at first, assuming its inferiority to other animated Fox sitcoms, which will remain nameless.  The concept of a talking baby and dog just seemed outright lame to me.  As often as I'm wrong about everything else in life, I was hugely mistaken with Family Guy.  The show offers fresh snappy material with each new episode, though I'm disappointed with the recurring episodes recently.  Characters are unique and hiliarious, and while we haven't all that much depth to them yet we are only in the third season.The main selling point of this show to me is their allusions and flashbacks. Like watching Dennis Miller, the show has witty references that send me into hysterics and appropriately zany humor for those of us that just want to laugh at something stupid.  The blend is impecable.  Scenes like the ghosts comforting Pac Man upon his split from Ms. Pac Man and Peter attacking the chicken that gave him an expired coupon are only a few prime examples.  With each reference to something in their past that impacted them later on they cover it by removing us from the scene and throwing us somewhere completely different.  It's truly refreshing, and only achievable in an animated sitcom.True this show can cross the line with classification-specific jokes, such as potentially religious and racist pieces.  But if you're paying attention you see the satire in it and how it often makes the joke in defense of the minority in a way that's still hilarious.  A show that can mix in political commentary that evokes a gutteral laugh outta me deserves a round of applause.  I PRAY this show stays on TV, cause once Frasier's out there won't be anything else worth watching on TV.  I'm not going to settle for Blind Date or Cheaters folks, I need something I can WATCH not just stare at in disgust.

Family Guy is my new favorite TV-show and for good reason. Family Guy is funnier, it's smarter, and it's better voice-acted than the Simpson's. Pretty much this is how it is. Peter Griffin is a simple family guy living in Rhode Island with a strange family. Lois is his loving wife and the only normal one.Stewie is there 2 year old son planning world domination, Meg is the drama queen daughter, Chris is the stupid son who doesn't understand anything, and Brian is there talking dog and the funniest of the all. With that the show brings forth a variety of hilarious characters and interesting scenarios including the apocalypse. What's makes this show brilliant is the way the incorporate modern themes and classical themes into the comedy. Soem parts are a bit more adult and on a few occasions goes to far but it's all in good taste. Each character has a great laugh and keeps the show going.Family Guy, I used too think was a show just trying to live up too the legend of cartoons that is now The Simpson. However Family Guy does not try to do this. The show is simply funny as hell and smart too. The show uses a lot of musical scenes, usually from famous films and make the scenes ten times as funny. It's great that FOX brought the show back and I hope they don't screw it up.Family Guy. Starring the voices of: Seth MacFarlane, Alex Borstein, Milas Kunis, and Seth Green.4 1/2 out of 5 Stars. Except for a few episodes.

I second the comments below me, Family Guy just wasn't very imaginativeor witty.  Cruelty and put-downs seem to be its stock-in-trade, and somegags are just in terrible taste (A dog panting, a woman walking by, looking at dog, and dog says, "Don't flatter yourself"??)
