If the 1980s were the decade for the sitcom, and the 1990s were the decade for Reality Television, then 2000s are the decade of the Animated Series. Proof positive is the unprecedented return of Fox's Emmy Award winning Family Guy.As popular television continues to focus more and more on The Real (A&E's Intervention), The Surreal (MBC's Fear Factor), and the mind-numbingly mundane (Cribs, The Real World, America's Top Model, Nanny 911, and Extreme -Blank- Makeover Ad Nauseum), the Animated Series offers writers and creators a literal blank canvas upon which to create all the laughter and drama we've come to expect from true television entertainment.And then there are the poop jokes.In Season 4, Episode 1 of Family Guy, titled North by North Quahog, Lois, Peter, Chris, Meg, Stewie, and Brian are all back for what promises to be a satisfying season. Those new to the show will be re-introduced to our old friends, but in their tried and true "developed" state, and die-hard fans will not be disappointed by the continuity of the characters and dialogue as the show transitions seamlessly from Season 3 to Season 4.As Seth himself said on the DVD commentary, in Season 4, the show is "...finally hitting its stride." If you are new to the show, give this a try! If you're a long-time fan, this season will not disappoint.

I hope this show will have a great impact on television comedy history. It really should. Family Guy is, to be completely honest, a very funny show. It has a lot a lot of laughs. That said, it is, to a certain extend, a rip-off of The Simpsons. I mean, looking at the families, Peter is Homer except even fatter and stupider, Lois is Marge except more whiny, Chris is Bart except, again, fatter and stupider, and Meg is Lisa except more unpopular and more of a nerd. Both families even have a dog and a baby (admittedly the Family Guy baby and dog are more entertaining than The Simpsons'). It's safe to say that without The Simpsons, there would have been no Family Guy. This is not to say that Family Guy should be dismissed. As I say, it is very very funny. It's potentially even funnier than the Simpsons. I think it probably is. One main difference, though, is that Family Guy, with characters which are really caricatures of themselves, lacks the depth of The Simpsons. The characters are really just there to deliver jokes, to a much greater extent than The Simpsons. So, my feeling is this: Family Guy is a terrificly hilarious show, and that is all there is to it.

Well done Fox for giving in and granting this superb slice of surrealism a fourth series, as it is one of the most innovative and funny adult comedies ever.For those of you unfamiliar with Family Guy's format, the Griffin family consists of fat, beer-loving couch potato Peter, sensible mom Lois, teenage daughter with problems Meg and naive Chris. So far so Simpsons. But when you discover the remaining two members of the family are Brian, a talking dog with a weakness for Martinis, and Stewie, a one-year old baby with plans for world-domination and severe matricidal tendencies, you get the feeling things aren't quite as straightforward as you thought.It has to be said that Family Guy's plot lines are nothing special, but where the shows genius lies is in its frequent, surreal flashbacks of life in the Griffin household. These couple the bizarre with the simply ridiculous, and there unpredictability is what gives the show's humour much of its bite. <example> Lois and Peter are talking about the theatre. Lois reminds Peter of the last time he interrupted a performance. Cut to a theatre performance of Cats. The three actors on stage dance around to music for around 30 seconds. The viewer will be spending this time trying to think of just how Peter interrupts the performance. What no-one expects is for Peter's car to suddenly drive through the set and run over one of the cats. it may just sound stupid here but see it on screen and you'd have to have the sense of humour of a rock not to laugh yourself silly.Possibly the most interesting characters in the show are Brian and Stewie. This may just be because they are the most surreal of the family, but they also have all the best lines and plot lines, especially in the special episodes "Road to Rhode Island" and "Road to Europe" where the terrible twosome leave their family behind to have their own adventures.With peripheral characters including sexual pervert Quagmire, Mayor Adam West (wonderfully voiced by the Batman star himself) and Death, Family Guy can definitely never be accused of taking itself to seriously. Family guy is wonderfully self-aware and, although frequent references to US TV shows and stars should in theory alienate non-American viewers, it rarely spoils the joke. In conclusion, Family Guy treads a fine line between intelligent satire and childish crudeness and comes out as the finest animated comedy ever, delivering its laughs with more frequency and consistency than the Simpsons ever did. Roll on season 4

Cheers to Fox for their experiments in new types of programming, and especially for their commitment to personality-laden animation. But "Family Guy" is a waste of time. The characters lack the engaging qualities of the Simpsons, the background setup makes no sense (what's the story on the talking dog? the talking infant?), nor do the attempts at "joke bombs" - ("Nice hooters," says a character about a female character; the female character is shown to be holding 2 owls on her arms for no other reason that to allow the "hooters" remark. Huh??) The animation is lackluster and uninteresting, there's nothing new or fresh or original about it, and most of all - It just ain't funny.

I LOVE this programme! I've heard others compare it to The Simpsons, but I dare say the writing for Family Guy is a thousand times more consistent than that of The Simpsons. Each time I watch, I fall to the floor laughing and I can not say that about that other show. Sure, at first glance, Stewie's character has the best lines, but his is only one level of a multitude that give me gut-wrenching guffaws. And to explain some of the ancient pop-culture references from the 70s and early 80s to today's so-called generation of 20-somethings makes a withered old crone as myself giddy beyond belief. Hooray, Seth MacFarlane, I'll be having your baby!

I know it's just a cartoon and it's obviously not real, but I HATE how they always have to incorporate animals getting killed/abused. Can't there be a TV show that doesn't include that kind of thing? They show it on several episodes and it's really just unnecessary and repugnant. Also, they have to throw in bashing on God in several episodes, too. Other than that it's a good and funny show.

Why did Fox take this show off the air? Of all the shows that fox could have removed form syndication it removes one of the best ones. Family Guy is well written animation comedy about a family living in Rhode Island. The potential of this show could be seen on the pilot episode. And yet it's off the air while the Wanda Sykes show is going on strong. Fox has no idea what they have done and to all the haters out there probably don't get the jokes or there just a bunch of fairies.

This, by far, is one of the funniest, and best shows in television history. Everyone can easily enjoy it. But, it, at times, can be out of line. And by out of line, I mean very out of line! Some jokes are funny while others are extremely racist, and offensive. There was even a joke about 9/11! Also, in one episode, The writers even had the nerve to show the prophet Muhammad's face! Some may think it's not that big of a deal. But, I even get offended when they show Jesus's face. But, all in all, it is still a funny show. It is very enjoyable! The time that they revealed that Stewie was gay was priceless! Despite how inappropriate the show can be at times, you just can't stop watching it. It's just too funny. The comedians who make up the jokes deserve a pat on the back, at least for the appropriate jokes. The characters are hilarious, lovable and One can easily be attached to one. So, I recommend that more people watch it. It truly is a fantastic show to watch!

just have to say that family guy is a breath of fresh air. the Simpson's was funny but is just getting old, they're on to their 18th season now, so some new material like family guy does not bother me one bit. Family guy has some great characters, from the homicidal baby stewie to a talking family pet, the humor just keeps on coming the stories are varied and the plot sticks, if something happens in an episode, well it will stay that way in episodes to come Seth Mcfarlan has created a real funny comedy so fox, stop editing and censoring and just let have some real, un-censored anti-bush propaganda please p.s screw George bush and America

Now, I know prime-time animated shows have been on the upswing in the past few years, most likely as a result of TAKING AWAY CARTOONS ON SATURDAY MORNING, but that's a rant to be addressed elsewhere. In any case, I can understand why Fox wanted more cartoons in prime-time; what I can't understand is why they settled on this particular one. Just because it's a cartoon does not implicitly make it funny, which it is overwhelmingly not.We've seen the big doofus dad before ("The Simpsons", "Dinosaurs", ad infinitum...), the smarter yet still doting mom (reference the same shows), the undersized megalomaniac ("Pinky & The Brain"), etc., etc., etc...  So we don't have much original concept to work with, which would be okay if the script made up for it. Again, no jackpot. Aside from a few chuckles--mostly incited by the baby or the dog--nothing really entertains here. What's worse is the offensive, stupidity-mistaken-for-irreverence crudeness of some of the jokes. A female newscaster, thinking she's been knocked off the air, says, "Well, I hate black people." Ha. Ha. A child (in one of those incessantly annoying asides) holds up his JFK Pez dispenser, which promptly gets its head blown off by a bullet. He then remarks on how lucky he is to still have his Bobby Kennedy Pez dispenser, and... well, it's simply too asinine to recount.Many people have stated how this show is the next "Simpsons". Wrong. Other than a general similarity in family structure, nothing else even compares. What "Family Guy" lacks most from "The Simpsons" is blatantly obvious, or should be: Writers. Humor. Satire. Everything that makes Homer and Co. so great is simply not in this show. With any luck, Fox will do some shuffling, put "King of the Hill" back on Sundays, rescue "The P.J.'s" from failing to deliver on the incredible potential it's been thus far ignoring, and send "The Family Guy" to a nice spot in Hell.

Peter Griffin seems to be the dumbest guy on the planet. He is lazy, very racist, and does not respect women. He has no respect for his wife, Lois, and yet she supports him and is faithful to him. He seems poorly educated and ignorant, does not take women seriously, and is mean to his daughter. It sends the message that if you are not pretty as a women, that you are worthless and don't deserve any respect. It is trying to counter what society is trying to accomplish by not taking women very seriously. Quagmire is also very chauvinistic. He does not develop a true relationship with women and is very shallow. This show is filled with gender-biased stereotypes and is racist.

Family Guy isn't funny at all. Here are some of my reasons why I believe this. 1) The plot goes nowhere. A story never gets told. Even with The Simpsons and South Park there is at least some kind of discernible story whereas Family Guy really goes nowhere. 2) The jokes seem forced. It's as if the writers run out of ideas after the first five minutes of the show, and so they have to push any type of joke they can fit in. 3) The punchlines are too long. In a scene of the Willy Wonka parody episode, Peter runs home and hits his knee, then he sits and groans for about 30 seconds. In that 30 seconds, that joke went from funny to irritating. Another is when Peter fights a giant chicken. The fight went on so long that it gave me a chance to find my remote control. 4) The characters are underdeveloped and obnoxious. Granted, while Stewie and Brian are great, every one else is a one note shallow character. Meg constantly whines, Chris doesn't seem to have any personality at all (besides being stupid, but can that be considered a personality trait?) Lois is just Marge Simpson incognito and Peter is just annoying. All other characters seem to be there to just make one-liner jokes. 4) The animation style is derivative and dull. It looks like the shows creator, one Seth McFarlane, said to himself "Well, The Simpsons look like this, so I will just draw my characters like this to copy the look without being too obvious." Part of the charm of similar shows like Simpsons and South Park was that there was nothing else like it on television. Family Guys look seems like a spin-off of the Simpsons.I hope my point has been made. Take a look and find how many other superior shows like "The Tick", Greg the Bunny", "The Critic" and "Clerks" get shelved and forgotten while something as unfunny and pedestrian as "The Family Guy" gets new life on T.V, and you'll see why I don't like this show.

Family Guy has been out since 1999 and I still don't get enough of it. Every episode literally makes me Laugh Out Loud. When you hear some of the jokes that they say in the show you wonder how they can get away with it either because their to inappropriate or because they are to racial. I recommend this show to anyone that hasn't watched it even though its a very popular show. I like this show a ton because I am a big fan of Seth McFarlane. I love how Seth McFarlane does almost all of the voices of the people on the show. I am a big fan of comedy movies and TV shows so this is a big hit for me. I love when new episodes come out because I have seen almost every single one of them. I strongly recommend you watch this and you too will Laugh Out Loud over the things they do and say!

Family Guy was, without a doubt, one of the 5 funniest shows I have ever seen on network TV.  In the first season, you would see a gag and go, "*laughing* Oh my god, that is hilarious!"  In the second season you would see a gag and go, "*laughing harder* Oh, my god, that is hilarious!  Can they even do that?!"  In the third season, however, you would see a gag and go, "Hehe, that's pretty funny...haven't I seen that before?"  This was due to the fact that after the show was feared cancelled after the second season (despite winning an Emmy!), many of the good writers left, and they had to hire new ones when the show was renewed.  Of course, Fox had to kill the show by giving it the same time slot as Friends...why must they do that?!? Nothing can beat Friends, which sucks for whatever has to share that time slot. Anyway, what made Family Guy funny for me was the laugh-a-minute joke setup, with occasional shock humor (like a 70s-era Peter running up to Charles Manson and several others and saying, "You guys!  I just got invited to a party at Sharon Tate's house!  Now you guys can come, but you gotta promise not to embarass me...").  The kind of jokes that were filled to the brim with pop-culture references that would make you point and laugh and think, "What must (whoever's being made fun of) think of that?" (or sometimes, "Why would (whoever) so shamelessly skewer THEMSELVES?"). Of course, I would like to praise Cartoon Network for picking it up for the station's "Adult Swim" time slot, and that there will be a DVD released. Rest in peace, Family Guy, and may you get a resurrection soon enough.

Family Guy is the funniest, the smartest, the greatest... need I say more? Creater Seth Mcfarlane plays the voices of Peter, The stupid father, the dog Brian, who has a bit too much to drink, and Stewie, the baby who is trying to take over the world and kill his mother. Their is also Lois, the mother, who is a piano teacher, Chris, the son, who has to face problems such as being more "endowed" then his father, and an evil monkey in his closet. Then there is Meg, the daughter who is embarrassed by her family and the biggest geek in her class who desperately wants to fit in. My favorite character is Stewie, because of all the crazy things he says and his voice. Seth Mcfarlane is brilliant for being able to put this show together. It got canceled after its 3rd season, but due to huge demand of DVD sales (Some stores were sold out the first day) It got put back on the air. This is a great show, and if you don't mind a few politically incorrect jokes, then you should watch it.

I'll go ahead and say it, I never payed ANY attention to Family Guy until about June 2002. It just didn't seem funny in the ads. But I did watch it, and I'm the happiest man on Earth because I decided to watch it. I think the reason I didn't watch it was because they used Stewie to promote it. He's not nearly as funny as Peter, whom they should've used to promote it. It's clever, well-written, nicely drawn, edgy, fast, and just wicked funny. There's nothing in the show that's taken seriously, like a lot of stuff in The Simpsons and Futurama. There's never a sad ending, everything's back to normal, and they just said something stupidly funny. There's something about The Simpsons that I've always wanted to address. It's a CARTOON! You can do anything in a cartoon, yet The Simpsons is more like a sitcom than a cartoon, because they fail to do anything ridiculous. In Family Guy, you can get transported to Narnia through a dryer, you can have a talking dog, you can turn the house into a giant puppet, you can become Death, become a fantastic pianist only when you're drunk, meet Death, or lose all your bones! The sky's the limit with this show! My favorite thing about the show is, nothing, I mean nothing, is taken seriously, and everything's turned into a joke. Everything sentimental is broken by a fart. A lesson learned is turned into a punchline. The jokes just never stop coming at you!

I didn't see Family Guy when it first came out. I didn't start watching it until its "second season" (has this show gotten through a full season?). Anyway, this show represents something that has been missing from most of today's comedies...sheer absurdity. I think that the high point of this came in one episode where Peter refuses a coupon, stating "I had a bad experience once" -- which digresses into a ten minute flashback involving a fight with a giant chicken (not a man in a chicken suit, an actual chicken!). This level of outrageous slapstick and zinging parody hasn't been seen since the glory days of the Simpsons (mid 90's, about when Seinfeld was really pumping out catchphrases). Things look bad for this show, but I sincerely hope that Fox hasn't given up on the Family Guy, since it's one of the few shows on TV to have critical acclaim AND viewer interest.

"Family Guy" may have ultimately turned into one of the most disappointing television shows that I have ever viewed. Not to say that the show is terrible or completely unfunny, as it is neither. In fact, "Family Guy" can still be considered better than your average television sitcom. I suppose what truly makes "Family Guy" so disappointing is that it began as a show with so much promise, only to become a predictable routine in a matter of years.Created by Seth MacFarlane and released in 1999, "Family Guy" introduced the world to the Griffins, the family that "Family Guy" revolves around. Peter and Lois Griffin, along with their children Meg (a decidedly unpopular high school girl), Chris (an unintelligent and overweight teenage boy), and baby Stewie (a maniacal and seemingly intelligent child bent on killing his mother), and the family dog Brian (who can talk, drink alcohol, and is very smart) became extremely memorable characters. A different type of humor was used in "Family Guy", where nothing was considered sacred. OK, so maybe "Family Guy" was not the first show with those principles, but it used them in such a different way. Episodes of "Family Guy" usually contained a plot, but it was all laced with various references to different subjects, ranging from politics to pop culture. To add to that, "Family Guy" did not keep traditional boundaries as far as content is concerned, causing considerable controversy (for instance, one episode shows Peter wishing he were Jewish, poking fun at both Catholic and Jewish religion). Due to this, "Family Guy" was canceled twice by FOX (the station it aired on), but constant pressure from fans always brought it back. Indeed, the first three seasons of "Family Guy" made the show into one of my favorite television shows of all time, topped only by "The Simpsons". It is a shame that the show took an unexpected downturn so suddenly.Mabey the writers of "Family Guy" became blinded by the success of their own show, but whatever creativity that went into the early episodes has been gradually lost. Sure, "Family Guy" always had its flaws, mainly in the fact that it presented so many jokes and gags at once that it was inevitable for a fair amount of them to fall flat. Still, the good jokes usually outweighed the bad ones in the earlier episodes. For the newer episodes, I do not know if that still holds true. Most of the jokes given in present episodes of "Family Guy" have no creativity at all, mainly making obscure references to pop culture. Is simply saying that a random movie sucks enough to make a joke work? No, I do not believe so, but that is what "Family Guy" seems content with doing now. Actors, political figures, and musicians are still regularly lampooned in episodes, but in almost no other way than saying they are poor at what they do or portray them as monsters (literally). Honestly, I have come to expect much more than that from "Family Guy".Just as bad as those jokes is the character development now present in "Family Guy". Sure, the characters seemed varied and interesting at first, but they have simply become stagnant. We now foresee that Peter's friend Quagmire is going to attempt to have sex with a woman, the town pedophile Herbert will make a comment on a young man that he finds attractive, and Brian and Stewie will engage in long bouts of dialouge that are meant to be craftful and humorous but end up being simply long winded and pointless. Actually, Brian is a very odd character all together. Brian is a talking dog that experiences human experiences, such as relationships with human women. Perhaps the writers wish us to follow Brian as if he is a human, but seeing a dog go through such experiences is a little much to take in. It is painful to admit, but I can now go through whole episodes of "Family Guy" without even cracking a smile.Occasionally, an episode will come along that does some to return the glory that "Family Guy" once had (such as the one where the Griffins go to Texas), but majority of the new episodes are just disappointing. Fond memories of early "Family Guy" episodes still resonate with me, however, and that is what made me give the show the score I gave it (which is still not very high). Overall, it is just sad for me to see a show that I thought, at one point, do no wrong go so terribly awry. Indeed, it is just disappointing.

It truly amazes me that a network could cancel a show like this.  They claim the ratings were never there, but then why is it that everyone from high school to mid-20s talks about this show as being even funnier than the Simpsons?  During my four years in college, everyone did Family Guy quotes. If the ratings were never there, maybe it was because viewers could never FIND the show because they kept changing its time slot every couple weeks. It really doesn't get funnier than this show.  Thank God it's being released as DVD.

This cartoon from the start has always been funny, The Simpsons was my all time favourite cartoon but eventually got old and worn out. Family Guy has ripped films off in some of its episodes such as American Beauty thats what i like about it, There is a movie coming out which should be funny,So this is a Simpson beater and delivers the funniness we expect. My favourite character has to be Stewie his accent is really funny and the way he hates his own mum is funny, Chris has to be the character with the funniest voice and hes just stupid. Also Peter the star of the show is just proper stupid I'd like him and Homer Simpson to meet that would be weird. For sure this is the greatest cartoon of all time it gets a respectable 9/10 for its amazingly funny content!

"Family Guy" is the real deal.  Although it falls just short of "South Park," "Family Guy" completely obliterates "The Simpsons," but that hasn't meant anything for the past decade because Matt Groening's brainchild totally blows."The Simpsons" wish they could be as sharp and witty and hilarious as "Family Guy."  The Griffins rock out with their cock out.  Peter, Lois, Meg, Chris, Stewie and Brian surpassed the Simpsons about twelve seconds into the show's pilot episode.  It was so much more fresh and funny than "The Simpsons," and it showed "The Simpsons" for what it really was:  a washed-up, lame and terribly unfunny shell of what it used to be.Seth MacFarlane gave us network television's answer to "South Park," the brightest, most intelligent show on cable.  Like Trey Parker and Matt Stone, MacFarlane packed a million laughs into every minute while providing strong political and social satire.  "The Simpsons" has never done that.  The only show on FOX that was better than "Family Guy" was "King of the Hill," which will wrap-up it seventh sensational season this weekend despite airing alongside garbage like "The Simpsons," "The Pitts," "Malcolm in the Middle" and "Oliver Beene."It is a shame that the show was canceled, probably to stroke Groening and company's tremendous ego, but it lives on through the wonders of DVD.  The first two seasons (28 extraordinary episodes) are now available on DVD, and the third and final season (another 21 excellent half-hour installments) is due out this fall.I also suggest watching other cult favorites such as "Duckman," "The Tick" and even "Futurama," which at times was very uneven."Family Guy" was an underrated and unappreciated animated sitcom.  A true television gem.***1/2 out of ****

Okay,this show is basically every fanboy's wet dream,whether it's a comic book fan or a Trekkie.This show has every reference to every pop culture being listed from A-Z.Sure,ya might not know most of them,but eventually you might get them.Some of my personal favorites are the references to musicals and actors of sort (Paul Lynde reference in 'The King is Dead' and the Grease spoof in 'Let's Go To The Hop').But the other thing that makes this show work,other than the cut-aways is the non-continuity bits.What this means is that they'll bring stuff up and never mention it again,like the Griffin's possibly real son 'Jimmy' being buried alive,or Lois finding Meg's tail,and we never hear of the incident again.One thing you'll have fun with this episode is guessing who's voice is who's.The main cast (those playing the Griffin family) has a huge amount of voices in this show,whether it's Seth Macfarlane playing Peter,Stewie,and Brian,or Seth Green using his regular voice as an extra while acting as Chris as the same time.Again,if you like the many references to the breakfast cereal mascots or the simple New England idiocy of Peter Griffin,you'll enjoy this better than the Simpsons.

If you are a fan of "The Simpsons" you should tune into Family Guy! More creative than The Simpsons, Family Guy is a little more "adult oriented." If you are a fan of 70's & 80's pop culture, you will LOVE Family Guy! There is so much satire and comedy, you will enjoy every minute of it. And just like The Simpsons, you have your beloved characters. Peter, Lois, Chris, Meg, Brian and Baby Stewie are The Griffin Family of Quahog, Rhode Island.Family Guy has been on (and off) the air since January 1999, and Fox continues to place this wonderful show in the worst time slots. (opposite Friends and Survivor) Now because of the decline in ratings, Fox has announced they will cancel Family Guy after this season.You should all tune in and give this wonderful comedy a chance.We beg FOX not to cancel it!

I truly loved Family Guy for the first few seasons it was originally on. Before it got cancelled, it was without a doubt my favorite show on television and each episode would leave you laughing for the next few days. I don't know what happened. Whether they fired all of their writers when the show was brought back on the air or what but Family Guy has become progressively worse. It is now filled with dumb random jokes, absolutely horrible writing, cheap shock humor, and is on a mission to shove its political views down your throat. You may still get an occasional cheap laugh but in the end Family Guy will leave you unsatisfied and empty. I'm sorry to say the show i fell in love with is now dead.

There.  I SAID IT.  Without the Simpsons, there would be no Fat Guy.  I'll be the first to admit it: Simpsons is nowhere near as funny or entertaining as it was even a couple of seasons ago and yeah, it's finally starting to wear a bit thin (thanks to the less than stellar writing).  But it still gets more laughs from me than Family Guy, which hits a funny note once or twice throughout the whole show, where jokes are fired off at a rapid-fire pace.  The fat father and baby come off as somewhat amusing and the mom and dog have the beginnings of a personality.  Unfortunately, they're not funny. The kids are neither funny; nor do they have a personality.  They may as well not even be there.  Every time I happen to catch an episode on Adult Swim, I can keep a straight face with hardly any effort at all.

I started watching Family Guy like... 6 months ago, and I really like it. Most of the jokes are funny and for the most part, the episodes have solid stories, so you might be wondering why I only gave this an 8. There are a few reasons, but the main one is this.The point of most of the episodes are meant to impose a view or belief, which is normally fine, but in this case, Seth Macfarlene sometimes does things that pretty much say: If you aren't a Liberal, you're an idiot. I could care less about politics, but I don't think they should put things like that in the show. It's not going to do much for you, except for get you to lose your fans. I don't care too much about it, which is why I gave it an 8. I'm just saying, it gets annoying. Honestly, the producers should know that they aren't going to get a bigger fan base by being a douche to half of America.

"In a wacky Rhode Island town, a dysfunctional family strive to cope with everyday life as they are thrown from one crazy scenario to another." That doesn't nearly express how great of a show this is. While other sitcoms take express jabs at character and ethnic views, this one goes straight to the metaphorical flea market known as "popular culture". Call it degrading, call it amoral, call it wrong - actually, you are, because I let my children watch it and I find it to be surprisingly tame - it sort of makes kids think they're getting away with something.It contains the following: Peter, a dumb gentle giant of a father, Lois, his wife whose voice an be compared to scrubbing one's ear with a Brillo pad, Meg, their unpopular daughter with social problems, Chris, a son who appears to have come from Peter's side of the family, Brian a talking alcoholic dog who thinks of a martini and a novel as a "wicked good time", and Stewie, a one-year-old who intends to kill Lois, but now must deal with his lack of bowel control and a British accent that comes out of nowhere.Very strict or Christian parents should think twice before letting their children watch this, but for those kids who like to repeat every childish, profane, and immature thing they hear, this is a goldmine.

It was good. I like the show, but the quality has declined already!!! Not that great. Not in my top 5 favorite shows, possibly 10, definitely 15. Absolutely no comparison to The Simpsons. The Simpsons was perfect (especially the older seasons). Whoever thinks this is their favorite show, the best show, or better than the Simpsons it so stupid. Not that great. I gave The Simpsons a 10, wouldn't mind if it gets canceled (they actually did get canceled, and a few years later came back, didn't affect me when they left). And when I heard that Cleveland's leaving, I was so mad. And I was annoyed when Bonnie gave birth, hope they do better.

the day i watched the family guy was the day i noticed everything the Simpson's was missing...humor. don't get me wrong, I've been a Simpson's fan since i was 5. but the past few seasons i found were getting lame and violently religious. if there not talking or going to church there violently mutalateing someone. that used to be funny... 10 seasons ago. the family guy offers a different kind of humor. the funny kind. i can sum up the family guy in 2 words freakin Hilarius's. i think my favorite character has got to be stewie, the world dominating 1 year old. my only question about him is can they understand him cause sometimes it seems that they can and sometimes they can't. I think my favorite episode is when stewie gets drunk and starts hitting on a hooker and talking to her about the molecular theory. or when chris witnesses a robbery and when he goes to identify him, peter walks in to the room and goes up to the robber and says, "have you seen my son, he's here to identify a robber, his name is chris griffin, here i have picture, you can go ahead and keep that chris messed it up by writing his class schedule and list of fears on it.

The rest of the episodes, I've got on the computer...This is by far one of the funniest shows of all time.  This show is full of satire, pop-culture references, and slapstick.  Seth MacFarlane has excellently blended these elements to create a show that keeps you laughing with unexpected twists and turns.Yeah, I'm a fan of the Simpson's, and this show is like the Simpson's in several areas.  But there are several more areas where they differ.  The Simpson's are usually much more realistic and a family.  Family Guy exploits the families problems and is often very far-fetched.  Which creates a different hilarity than the Simpson's.I don't understand Fox.  They push that insipid Malcolm in the Middle like none other, not even realizing it succeeds because they put it right after the Simpson's.  They easily could have put Family Guy there, and had a two hour animation block that would have kept audiences rolling.  But, no, life is not perfect.To sum it up, it's a great show, it deserves more credit than it got, watch it on Cartoon Network, and maybe notice that recently, Simpson's have copied some ideas from it.
Interesting to see this writer so keen on writing within this context. At this point, it would be joke in itself to see some *creativity* surrounding his own beliefs.

I cannot precisely tell you the effect the first few seasons of "Family Guy" had on me. I was hooked. Some episodes were of pure comedy genius and I'm all nostalgic just thinking about them.However as I watched more and more episodes I noticed something changing. This wasn't the same spontaneous, crazy, out of this world show that I so used to love. It turned in a show where Brian tries to give me philosophy lectures of why God does not exist. Don't get me wrong as I'm not easily offended especially by a comedy show. Humour is supposed to satirize. Yet I never see them making fun of Muhammed for that matter either. It's probably for the best, otherwise they would long have cancelled the show. I'm saying all this because for me there's a difference between cheap, morally and religiously offensive, disgusting sexual jokes and clean and smart humour. At first it didn't tend to rely on the former as much as on the latter. That is real humour for me, not degenerated jokes. That is how a real comedian shows his genius, by not relying on sexually explicit jokes and mediums.I sincerely hope that one day "Family Guy" will move back to the good old fashioned values of humour it used to rely on. That was what made it so unique and worthwhile for me.

"Hey Have some gum" "Thank you" "HAHAHA that was joke gum!!" "what do you mean?" "Now you're addicted to heroin HAHAHA!" (shivers) "I'm Cold" Ypu definitely have to watch this show.

This is by far the funniest cartoon ever. I love the randomness and the many movies they make fun of with out you even knowing it was making fun of the movie. You can take one episode and watch it ten times and find something new to laugh at each time. Why in the world did they cancel it, and I hope the guy who got it canceled got fired. It's incredibly difficult to truly know where to begin with 'Family Guy'. It has been criticised and applauded in equal measure since its conception and neither side truly wants to (or will ever) back down. Its detractors call it shallow, uncouth, repetitive and plagiarists, whilst its legions of devoted followers see it as a truly unique and brilliant product of out time.To be perfectly honest I'm gonna sit on the fence for this one. I hugely enjoyed it when I saw the first season and was able to appreciate the fact, that whilst hugely derivative of other shows it openly recognised this and took pleasure in lampooning its own shortcomings.However, aside from its cult devotees that will take pleasure in the show regardless of the directions that it takes; few can deny that the quality of the more recent crop of episodes has dropped in standard. Seemingly desperate to maintain the juggernaut momentum that it gathered through its first opening runs and the gargantuan DVD sales that it accumualated thereafter, it has appeared to have taken its own formula and mercilessly flogged it for absolutely everything that its worth.Popular culture references, slapstick, wordplay, surreal flashbacks and an almost endless string of parodies, puns, puerile sex gags, situational oddities and 'South Park'-style political satire. All have been crammed, squeezed and mashed together seemingly at random into exhaustingly short episodic spans of times. This would be great if they were building on a rock solid base of core material, but unfortunately they seemed to have sidelined the character building exercises and true narrative structure of the first couple of seasons for an almost breathless onslaught of punchlines and out-of-nowhere jokes that appear and disappear just as quickly.The primary result of all this is a rather empty feeling of dissatisfaction. You want to feel like you're laughing but its unclear what you're laughing at due to the vaporious nature of the 10-joke-a-second material.Don't get me wrong - There is undoubted genius here. It just feels so insubstantial given that there's no real structure or cohesive method of storytelling that I found it somewhat dull and lifeless after a few episodes. Seth McFarlane and his writing team clearly have an undisputed knack for bang-on-the-money, bizarre humour but it would appear to me that in their desperation to keep with their obvious peers - 'South Park' and 'The Simpsons' - they've gone and given us too much of a good thing. Maybe this is their intention and they're making a statement regarding the huge flow of available information in this day and age. Maybe not, either way its never too late to reclaim back lost ground (Unless you get cancelled again in which case, tough tits).P.S. One major trend I've noticed throughout this body of reviews in particular is that a large proportion of those with a 'pro' agenda haven't taken the time to correct their typo's. Spell proficiently if you want people to take you seriously! Cheers for the hating ;-)

Okay, "Family Guy" is one of the most remarkable, hilarious shows of all times. It uses jokes that reference, history, pop culture, and it even has (sometimes funny) toilet humor. The May 1st episode is no exception. However... Seth MacFarlane should consider rethinking what he chooses to satire. I think that religion and politics have no place in "Family Guy" (other than the occasional reference). Past episodes of "Family Guy" have not had quite so many political and religious puns as did the May 1st episode. It is a no-brainer that Seth MacFarlane is a democrat/liberal. However, he should realize that "Family Guy" is watched by millions of people, some that are Catholic and yes some that are republican. While the May 1st episode was not TOO offensive, I could see him turning this amazing series into the unfunny mess that "American Dad" is. MacFarlane should realize that approximately 80% of American people are Christian and HOW much money did "Passion of the Christ" make? Also, half (or more than half) of America is republican and that includes a lot of his viewers. His whole comeback is based on whether he can gain viewership and if he keeps doing this he may notice a decline in Nielsen ratings. I hope that he sticks with the hilarious pop culture references and funny jokes that have nothing to do with politics and religion and leaves that spoofing to his piece of trash..."American Dad"

This is one of the funniest animated programs ever!!!! It may not have the simpsons quality in political jokes but if you want that you just watch futurama. I have bought the entire DVD set of family guy and it cannot be beaten!! From cleveland's slow delivery of wife complaints to Quagmires sexists jokes (LOL) and catchy lines (oh Yeah, giddy giddy giddy!!)It takes the mickey out of everyone and it is marvelous.ps Sherlock my favourite character would have to be stewie for his one liners and his all round comedy. he is the funniest thing to hit television since the start of that red dwarf with the singing (tongue tied by cat, lister and rimmer) (parallel universe is the episode name).

This show was canceled 3 times only to come back after each time after huge fan support.If that doesn't describe a cult hit, I don't know WHAT does.Anyway, if you're at this page on IMDb, chances are you already know what this show is about. The first season was hilarious right from the first episode, something that didn't happen with The Simpsons' first year since it was cheaply made and written, only saved from visual images and minor jokes here and there, great that the other Simpsons seasons were much improved, but moving on...The characters are great, Peter's idiocy is a big highlight of the show and Brian's sarcasm steals the show. Stewie and Chris are great too, as they have their great lines and story lines. Lois and Meg are funny as well.The second season is hands down the best season of this show and might just remain to be. Any episode from that year are good reasons to watch this. The third season was also hilarious with the episode about the South.The fourth year? It's alright but the jokes feel forced and too direct and sight gags are officially removed. It still jumps hoops over the current years of The Simpsons, but the episodes are getting weak, especially recently with the gay marriage episode, the "Peter gets shipwrecked" episode, and without a doubt, the episode where Peter and Lois gets high and start folk singing. I hope the upcoming fifth year is better as this is still the best show on FOX Sunday with it's spin off, American Dad, only second.There were so many evening cartoons that were thrown off the air quickly due to bad network treatment, but to be honest, some of those shows deserved it, but Family Guy is the only one of them that could stay alive after being left for dead so long and for so many times. People could call it a ripoff of The Simpsons and The Critic all they want, but it's original in it's own ways. Funnier, too.

Family Guy used to good but over the past few years it's lost it's charm and humour, They just keeps using the same lines and moments from previous episodes, they used them so much that it got boring, the sketches are good but too unrealistic, the characters are nice to watch for around the first half of the episodes but lose the charm because they stay in a pose for 4 seconds and then change to a different pose, a few jokes hit but it isn't enough to get engaged into the story. The old episodes however are enjoyable to watch, slightly annoying but you learn to forgive it cause of the hilarious humour and good animation, Definitely watch them, Overall, Try and avoid New Family Guy, it sucks

The funniest thing about this show is clearly Stewie. While generally the humor is funny and unpredictable, Stewie Griffith has to be one of the great comic characters of the last fifty years. He's right next to Homer Simpson, whom, Peter Griffith happens to be a fairly obvious exploitation of. But Stewie has no counter-part, no predecessor. He is wholly unique. At times he may remind you of Calvin, from the immortal comic strip "Calivin and Hobbs" but largely the things you will find Stewie saying have never come out of any other one year old in the history of the world or entertainment. But what so many of the show's fans fail to realize is that the show is actually done from the perspective of Stewie. This is the only way it makes sense.Watch the show with this idea in mind. The way the family reacts to Stewie's absolutely outrageous banter is usually perplexing. They seem to understand his intentions, his feelings, usually anger, but do not acknowledge his eloquence, articulate speech, or homicidal intentions. The dog, Brian, is a good indication as well. The fact that the dog is intellectually and morally superior to the humans in the family seems to be perfectly suited to a young child's view of animals. These two characters, by far the most intelligent of the family, also seem to share a unique understanding of one another. Brian is the only member of the family who actually understands everything about Stewie's personality, identifies it, responds to it, and even mocks it. Stewie does the same with the dog. While the rest of the family move moronically along through preposterous stories, the two characters who, in any other sitcom would be background scenery, snicker to one another and observe. Sometimes they take an active role in the plot, but this is usually when the plot pertains directly to one or both of them.

When i first saw this on sky TV around 3 years ago,I assumed it was another animated comedy about the pros and cons of an American family to join the likes of Simpson's and King of the Hill. Then i thought.. Wait a second.i LOVE these programs. My brother bought the first and second series as soon as they were available and I'm afraid I've been hooked since. It took me about a year to accept that the voice of Chris was heartthrob Seth Green, but once I had accepted this life became easier. =] My favourite series I think has to be 1. Due to its fresh and different material. To be honest I wasn't AS impressed with the Stewie movie - it was funny but it could have been stretched into another series. My favourite character has to be "Lando Griffin". Don't do Toad,Kids.

Family Guy is easily the funniest animated series I've ever seen (with Home Movies coming in a close second), and is leagues ahead of The Simpsons in every way. The characters are more interesting, the jokes are funnier (although far less PC), and the show is altogether fresher than the overly stale Simpsons. Basically, if you're a fan of The Simpsons (and aren't easily offended), you should like Family Guy.One of the series' greatest strengths is in its reliance on an ensemble cast rather than depending on a single character to carry the entire show. Most of the characters are equally funny and no one is ever really reduced to playing Peter's straight man. Even the supporting characters (and a lot of the minor characters, for that matter) can be just as funny as the main characters and this leads to a refreshing change of pace from the typical animated comedy focusing on a lone frontman.The only area that The Simpsons can claim to have a hand up in is that of continuity. There are several glaring continuity errors in Family Guy (most are made in an effort to tell a random joke) that can be distracting if you're unable to suspend your disbelief. They aren't overly noticable... but for the nitpicker... they're there.Simply put, if you like The Simpsons (and can stand a few offensive jokes), you should love Family Guy. The latter is more intelligent (with references ranging from Marlowe to Warhol to Dallas to Jenna Jameson), funnier and altogether less tired and rundown. With new episodes set to come out next year, it's definitely worth a look.

Family Guy.  In a nutshell, brilliant!Personaly I think that this series is one of the best I have seen for a long time.  Better than Futurama and Seth MacFarlane's previous efforts.Definatley one to watch!  Highly recommended.

This show is, without a doubt, the funniest animated program on television, easily trumping the aging "Simpsons."  Nowhere else is "Family Guy's" unpredictable, spontaneous style of humor duplicated (perhaps the unfairly short-lived NBC sitcom "Working," but this show really takes it to a whole new level beyond that).  The series relies less on seeing how a storyline will develop than the Simpsons (not that that's entirely absent) and more and attacking the viewer with a constant barrage of jokes and one-liners, which it pulls off surprisingly well.  The way this show delivers laughs by catching viewers by surprise would work well enough on its own, however, the writers go the extra mile with jokes that are also clever and lines that are very quotable.As the Simpsons will likely pass soon, Family Guy should be stepping in as its rightful successor, NOT being cancelled.  Goodness knows, if there's any show that deserves to be saved from cancellation a second time, it's this one.

This is easily the funniest animated series to come along since the Simpsons. Nothing else even comes close. The writing is brilliant with each episode and never slags for a laugh unlike the Simpsons recently which tends to be a tad boring at times.Forget Futurama. Don't even waste your energy on King of the Hill (which is probably the unfunniest animated show in history). Save Family Guy!I cannot for the life of me understand how Fox would want to kill this show. They put it on against Survivor and Friends yet expect it to deliver ratings? No, that is where you put a show if you want to KILL a show. It is wholly inentional. And a shame.Hopefully, someone at Comedy Central or some other network like UPN or WB could give this gem a fresh start. Hopefully it won't be buried like the Critic was (another damned fine show as well).Brian and Stewie are incredible. Peter is funny as hell as are the rest of the family. The in-jokes fly at warp speed and the show has not yet failed to make me laugh out loud at least a half dozen times per episode.Truly a brilliant creation and kudos to Seth MacFarlane@

Let me start by expressing my revulsion towards the Fox Network for moving "Family Guy" around, putting it in the death slot and eventually canceling a show adored by millions."Family Guy" was probably best known for its innovative inclusion of pop culture references and its uncompromising style of confronting common stereotypes.  Of course above all it was the funniest show I've ever seen! Part of its appeal was the enigmatic interaction of such diverse characters as Peter, the most politically incorrect and ignorant member of the family or Brian the intelligent, cynical talking dog or Stewie, the caustic and jaded talking baby whose barbs were a sheer delight to hear!  And that's just the main characters, let's not forget everyone's favorite pervert Quagmire!Another thing I loved about this show was that the humor never let up. Usually a comedy has a few bits that are 'laugh out loud' funny and the rest is filler.  Not "Family Guy".  The show was packed with gags, one after another.  Nothing else has managed to make me laugh as hard and as long as "Family Guy" has.A lot of people thought the show was offensive.  They're entitled to their opinions.  Personally though I think the show was socially cathartic.  It brought out all of the stereotypes regarding culture/race etc. out in open. When Peter refers to all Southern people as having bad teeth and suffering from the gum disease Gingivitis, he's just bringing a common stereotype out in the open.  Once people begin to face the fact that these stereotypes exist and are commonly believed ONLY THEN can we start to dispel them.Overall "Family Guy" was just a truly remarkable show.  If you missed it be sure to check out the US DVD release.  I'm sure you'll agree that such a witty and humorous show should not have been mistreated and canceled so early.  Fox has deprived us all and lost my viewership for many years to come.

This show is the best show ever, i love this show very much because of the jokes and the cut-offs. This show had everything and is quite possibly the funniest animated show ever made (including anime such as Dragon Half, Golden Boy and Ippatsu Kikimusume). The only other possible candidates that come to mind are The Simpsons (in it's 4th and 5th season golden age) and Stressed Eric (a little know British cartoon which I have only seen a few episodes of in it's bastardized, redubbed, American form.) I'm sorry to make the same cliched comparison to the Simpsons but it really is the only analogy that makes sense seeing as they're contemporary Fox cartoons targeted to the same audience with similar characters and humor, not to mention, as I said before, they are probably the two funniest cartoons ever made. But Family Guy is certainly not a rip-off of The Simpsons, even though it is clearly heavily influenced by it, if anything it is a successor to it (seeing as Family Guy came on the air at the same time that the Simpsons started to lose its brilliance). Peter, Lois and Meg may be very similar characters to Homer, Marge and Lisa, but Brian and Stewy are both incredibly unique. Family Guy's humor is also truly it's own, getting an equal number of laughs from pop culture satire, shock value and the just plain weird. It essentially relied on the surprise created by juxtaposing opposite, such as first featuring a joke so offensive that you couldn't help but laugh defensively and then immediately following up with an obscure quote from Voltaire. Even the extremely fast pace of the show was used to create an opportunity to do the exact opposite of what was expected, such as in one episode (Wasted Talent) when, as usual, jokes were flying at the rate of 3 or 4 a minute and then suddenly everything stopped with a 1:30 min. clip of Peter repeating the word "ow" after scraping his knee. When I watched this I remember being my confusion at the fact that they were wasting so much time to essentially dead air escalate until I was actually rolling on the floor laughing at the lack of a joke; the longer it went on the more time I had to appreciate just how hilarious it was that this show would intentionally do something so insanely unconventional. This was a truly amazing cartoon, and those who dismiss it because of the sometimes extremely offensive jokes aren't watching it correctly.

OK, you may think I must be mad because of the quick summary, but I believe it is better. The one reason for that is that the simpsons is shown too much. I mean, it is shown every night here in Melbourne, and I also know it is shown every night on the BBC. Most people would be bored of all the repeats (some classics never tire out however). Meanwhile, Family Guy is hardly shown, so old episodes are still funny.Now basically why I like this show so much is because of Stewie. Who needs Maggie Simpson when you've got Stewie. Stewie is a one year old who has one goal: total world domination. He has an English accent, and loves destroying things. While he is a good character, Peter and Brian are good too.There are many real life TV shows and movies made fun of in this show, and they are funny too. For example, in Star Trek, Captain Kirk moved from one place to another between every word, there was one where Peter ran over Road Runner, and Wile Coyote was in the car and told him he'd hit nothing and to keep going.The show is ruder then the Simpsons but not as rude as South Park. It is funnier then South Park though, and the show should never be cancelled (apparantly it was once). I rate it 10/10.

You cannot beat the comedy that the Family Guy has to offer. As the Simpsons rambles on year after year with less and less new episodes I had been looking for something entertaining in the Animated Comedy genre and The Family Guy filled the void. Not just the Main Characters, Peter, Lois, Stewie, Brian, Chris and Meg but the additional characters such as Quagmire, Joe, Cleveland, Mr. Weed and Cleveland Jr. make the comedy spread out over the show forcing you to watch because anyone could say anything. Personally I only watch the Simpsons to see what Homer has to say, but with the family guy an extra character could say something just as funny as the main characters. The Flashbacks and scene changes are a refreshing spin on the way animated comedy is conducted today. Personally, I think of it as the Seinfeld of Animated Comedies, You have to be smart to get it. I look forward to more episodes and can't wait for it to come out on DVD.

Family Guy is a cartoon show featuring the Griffin family airing regularly on Fox. The Griffins live in a fictitious town in Rhode Island called Quahog and are obviously meant to be a middle class family dealing with issues associated with that class. Family Guy poses as a typical sitcom in many respects. The show centers on a nuclear family, a theme which is anything but original in the sitcom genre. Many sitcoms have featured middle class families but Family Guy is not another generic sitcom. The cartoon is mean as a contemporary reaction to the media reality presented in the 1950s to the 1980s. Sitcoms, especially in the post-WWII era, idealized the middle class. The Griffins are very much parodies of the "perfect" families seen in such shows as Leave it to Beaver. As portrayed by the media, the middle class is supposed to be the bedrock of American society, standing alone in holding the rest of the country together. The Griffins are far from being America's moral compass. Family Guys is often criticized for using a crude, immature sense of humor. It is true the writers employ bathroom humor and foul language in the 30 minute episodes. What certain critics do not, however, realize is that this kind of humor serves a purpose. The humor of the cartoon characters dents the idea that all middle class families have impenetrable moral values. This makes Family Guy not only watchable but also relatable.The Griffins are over-exaggerations of middle class family life. This portrayal of the family as uncouth, gross, etc is a way to make the family more believable. Family Guy provides its audience with imperfect characters because it is hard to live up to stands set by other media. The coarse Peter Griffins telling an inappropriate story involving a rat while eating dinner with the "upper crust" of society at a yacht club, in the episode "Peter, Peter Caviar Eater" is a more likely depictions of most families than June Cleaver vacuuming in her pearls. The writers use this humor to attract desired demographic for advertisers. Shows and networks need to attract viewers because the ultimate reason for making television programming in America is to grab hold of viewers' attention and then sell us goods, through advertisements or product placement. Advertisers are especially interested in capturing the attention of the eighteen to thirty-nine year old male category. This demographic seems especially entertain by the foul language and bathroom humor of Family Guy. Young males, perhaps more than any other segment of the population, are believed to think pooping, farting, burping, etc is funny. Young males are also amused to see the traditional middle class family, meant to be wholesome, use foul language and toilet humor not usually associated with that class. Bottom line is: television is meant to be entertainment. People watch television to relax and unwind. After coming home from work, viewers don't want to think about complex things. The slap-stick humor used in Family Guy is anything but complex. Viewers are able to laugh at the shows on a very juvenile level. If you have never watched Family Guy, watch it! On a basic level it's entertaining to watch Peter Griffin stumble through various awkward social situations. On a higher level, the show provides witty commentary on a wide range of contemporary issues-both social and political. If Family Guy is not your idea of entertainment and humor, don't watch it. You can change the channel. No one is forcing you to watch the show. But maybe you could think about taking a page from the show and not taking yourself too seriously and enjoy a good childish laugh.

Geniuses with a sense of humor, thats the only way you can describe the creators and writers of Family Guy. With its sharp and clever jokes this adult cartoon proves to be a worthy adversary to the now stale Simpsons. The show centers around 6 characters. Peter (The wreckless and idiotic father) Lois (Poster Mom with a neurotic side) Chris (Talented yet dimwitted Son) Meg ( Social Outcast with a lonely sense of humor) Stewie (Maniacal genius with a very lonely side, and a slight gender confusion) and Brian (Intelligent alcoholic with a sarcastic wit). The Combination of these and many other facetious characters are what allows Family Guy to smash all other modern adult cartoons and make it a must see for all intelligent viewers!

I love this show. It makes me laugh out loud more than any other show. The Simpsons was the best for several years but lately it's just not funny. South Park is still hilarious. Pound for pound, minute for minute, though, Family Guy is the king. There are a guaranteed 35 new episodes coming in early 2005, and they have the same cast and most of the writers, etc. coming back. I can't wait!There are a lot of pop-culture references in any episode, and if you don't get them then obviously the show won't be as funny to you. Also, there are a lot of crude and low-brow jokes which may alienate the more prurient. Fine, then, go watch something else. I feel like this show was written specifically for me and my sense of humor.For an animated series, Family guy is the shizzle as far as I'm concerned. I also love South Park, and some of the shows on Cartoon Network's Adult Swim are hilarious (Harvey Birdman, Sealab 2021, etc.).I like absurdity, like when Peter refuses a coupon from a teen in a chicken suit outside a fast food restaurant. Flash back to the last time a chicken gave him a coupon. First of all, it's a real chicken, and huge. Turns out the coupon was expired. So Peter goes out and starts brawling with the chicken, for several minutes, in one of the most violent and epic fights ever, on trains, helicopters, office buildings...That's Family Guy.As Comic Book Guy would say, "Best...show...ever."

The Simpsons will forever be the yardstick against which every family oriented animated show will be measured. Futurama was an excellently animated show, rich with creativity. South Park indulges in its trademarked vulgarity and judgment. King of the Hill, while not appreciated by all, illustrates the funny side of everyday life with a traditional simple man. Now, from the talented mind of Seth MacFarlane, arrives "Family Guy"!No matter what your age or personality, "Family Guy" will appeal to you. The show is full of wacky flashbacks and pop culture references that, if you understand them, will make your sides hurt with laughter, and if you do not understand them, can still entertain you based on their absurdity. Furthermore, the political satire and somewhat sacrilegious aspect of the show should not be overlooked.The characters on the show are individuals you would come across in everyday life whom you may not realize are ripe with hilarity. Whether it is your intoxicated idiot friend Peter, smooth talking ladies man Quagmire, the attractive house wife Lois, the dog that you are sure you have conversed with while sipping a dry martini Brian, or even that baby you know with a British accent whose primary goal is to take over the world Stewie. Clearly, the characters that are unique to this show are the dog and especially the baby. Stewie will, without a doubt, make you laugh out loud, be it because of his plans of world domination or those of killing his mother. It is interesting to note that Seth has said, to him, when creating this show, Stewie was just an afterthought. It is funny that that slight afterthought is the most irreplaceable aspect of "Family Guy".After years of cultivation, beginning with his 1995 short "The Life of Larry," and sequel 1996 short "Larry and Steve," Seth MacFarlane gave rise to "Family Guy" in all it is glory. While the final features of "Family Guy" are somewhat altered from his two original shorts which I recommend every true "Family Guy" fan make an effort to find and watch, the basic premise remains the same; an idiot drunk of Irish descent living in Quahog, Rhode Island with this beautiful wife, three kids, and talking dog.At this point in time I would like to clear up a huge misunderstanding. Contrary to widespread opinion, when investing your time in "Family Guy", you are certainly not receiving a Simpsons rip-off. This show is much more edgy and fast paced, without crossing over into the radical crudeness of South Park.Fox did impair the ratings of "Family Guy" by switching it constantly when it was on air, which eventually led to it is cancellation. However, the opinions of Fox do not reflect those of the loyal fans of this show. Most fans were confused and devastated, spouting Stewie's catchphrase, "What the deuce?!" Recently we have received word, as of November 2003, that the return of "Family Guy" by March 2005 is confirmed, due to spectacular sales of the "Family Guy" DVDs. All of us devoted and obsessed fans anticipate a "Family Guy" era with sheer giddiness and enthusiasm. TO VIEW ALL EPISODES www.TV-series-stream.com/

Seriously, this is the best show I've ever seen.  It's completely hilarious; every time I see an episode, I laugh the whole way through.  Even if I've seen the episode before, there are so many little jokes that I always see something I missed before.  I never get tired of watching this show.  A lot of the humor is kind of offbeat, and some might think it's mean, but truly, as long as you don't have a stick up your behind, you'll get a kick out of it.  I'm devastated that this incredible show went off the air.  Seth MacFarlane is one of the most talented people ever; his characters amuse me to no end.

I didn't mention this earlier, but I happen to love the Simpsons.  A lot of people made comments bashing the Simpsons, Futurama and Malcolm In The Middle.  I personally really like all of these shows, and I LOVE Family Guy just the same.  Who cares if it's a little similar to the Simpsons?  You wouldn't see an episode of the Simpsons with the Pope getting knocked over by a hot air balloon carrying two of the main characters (Stewie and Brian), then the Pope coming over to say "You make a da Pope look like a fool! *looking up at the sky* SMITE HIM!!! *pointing at Brian and waiting...and waiting...*  He's a cookin' a something up!"  Family Guy was simply the best show ever created.  Putting other shows down really doesn't accomplish anything, except for perhaps alienating those who like the other shows. Give this show credit for its genius on its own merits, not compared to everything else.

I must admit, in its hype before the 99 superbowl, i had written family guy off as another married with children/simpsonesque ripoff and FOX's insistance on brian's line in the first ep "It's 5 30 and you still have your pants on...whats the occassion?"... oh how wrong i was. I became an ardent fan of the show...and bizarre jokes about the Lindbergh baby and Hitler's talk show kept the show edgy, but not in the South Park/Tom Green "Edgy for the sake of edgy" way. I have a TV hidden in my office just because Futurama and Family guy are run at 2pm and 2:30pm on TBS

i used to look forward to the new episodes of family guy on Sunday nights. but the last few episodes have been so poor that i cannot believe that they are still on the air. it seems like they ran out of material after the family guy movie. don't get me wrong the first 5 seasons were absolutely brilliant, but they seem to have hit a wall with the writing. The show used to be cutting edge and borderline inappropriate, but it seems like they took it down a notch. almost to the level of the Simpson's. where is the crazy antics that i am used to. it could be that i just have grown up from the family guy "age", but i am only 20 years old and still enjoy a good fart joke. i just hope that its family guys slump, and the will come out of it to be back on par with south park.

I really don't know how this show has lasted this long. My favorite show, "the critic" only lasted just more than 20 episodes. This show, in my opinion, isn't nearly as funny. "Family guy" is written in the same style (as "the critic") with pop culture references and flashback scenes but the humor just isn't laugh out loud type.In my opinion Peter's flashbacks are just a rip off of Jay Sherman's. Aside from the humor the characters aren't as defined as those in The Critic. I loved Jay's parents, Eleanor and Franklin, as well as his boss, his make up lady, his ex wife,his son, his sister, and his girlfriend, as well as countless other characters that rounded out the show to make for a hilarious, irrevrant comedy. Unlike The Critic the charactors in Family Guy just seem to hang around and don't help to round out the show. I hope Fox someday decides to revisit The Critic because it is in most ways much better than this show.

Don't Get me wrong-I love this show. Family Guy, The Simpsons, and South Park rank as the holy triumvirate of animated comedy shows; Family Guy mostly for its first, second, and third seasons. The first three seasons not only were a fresh turn of comedy in an era of stupid assembly-line sitcoms but were hilarious no matter how many times you watched an episode. There are so many quotable lines in Family Guy and every one is and will always be funny. The show had a great sense of timing as well as a different flavor of comedy that included the lampooning of many stars in the entertainment industry and references to the pop-culture icons of now and yesteryear, some references more archaic than others. There is also the famous "flashback sequence" that occurs in every show, in which a member of the family guy cast remembers something humorous that happened to him/her, and the sequence itself sometimes is the punchline. It's a bit hard to explain, but the formula worked for the first three seasons. However, I think that recently Family Guy has been in a steady decline. Maybe because they got new writers, maybe because Seth Macfarlane is putting all his energy into American Dad, which is, I don't care what people think, a F***ing riot; but Family guy just isn't as funny or as cerebral as it once was. Maybe it can redeem itself; the show hasn't fully jumped the shark yet, but they should pick up the slack on better jokes while their audience is as large as it is. This is my first comment, by the way.

I think that Family Guy is the best show ever.  I own all of the DVDs and I feel that all of you should do the same.  I believe that FOX lost big-time ratings when they cancelled the show.  Just look at what the Cartoon Network has done with it now.  I recently read that when  Family Guy was first released on DVD it was the highest grossing TV DVD of that year, and fourth of all time.  Many people compare the show with The Simpsons or King of the Hill.  I feel that this program has its own character and should not be compared with something just because it is an animated show.  The Family Guy has its own unique sense of humor that is outrageous and off-the-wall. The characters are fully developed, with each having their own input to the cohesiveness of the family.  I think that everyone should watch the show, on Cartoon Network's Adult Swim, to see the genious program that Seth MacFarlane has created.  So, if you want to experience the best TV program ever, I say watch the Family Guy; you'll be glad you did!

OK, so I don't think this comes to you as any surprise that this cartoon is not as good as 'The Simpsons', but it comes really close and this is why: 'Family Guy' takes the same approach as 'The Simpsons', in that it is structured around a family. Where 'Family Guy' is better here is that rather than to focus on other people in the town in some episodes instead of the family, the storyline revolves around each family member in almost equal amounts (including the baby and dog, who incidently can talk). This is unlike 'The Simpsons', which gives an unfair bias towards Homer and leaves out Marge.Its biggest strength however, is its jokes. It uses the same style as 'The Simpsons' with most of the jokes being intertextual references to other media, most of these are done better than 'The Simpsons', with the biggest problem being that they are sometimes too obscure to spot that particular reference.However, the programme does have its faults. Most episodes are packed so full of jokes that it seems almost just a matter of time before the programme will run dry (although thankfully this isn't evident in later episodes of the show!). Another factor is that although the animation is good, it is blander than something like 'The Simpsons' or 'Futurama' and therefore some of the audience will not give it a chance straight away.
Another problem is its obvious resemblance to 'The Simpsons' and although it doesn't feel like a rip-off of it, some of the jokes are in a very similar style. This is the main reason why I have used 'The Simpsons' as a main comparison. The storylines are also weaker than 'The Simpsons', as it relies heavily on the jokes.All in all 'Family Guy' comes very close to 'The Simpsons', with its biggest weakness being that its lasting appeal will never match that of 'The Simpsons'.

When "The Family Guy" came on the scene in 1999, it was thought to be a weak duplicate of the Simpsons. But it shortly established itself by branching out into avenues, few shows have ever dared to tread. The twisted and comical nature of the show, along with is fantastical cast (i.e. - Brian, Stewie, etc.) proved to be a unique asset, and showed just how far you could take animation. It brought aspects of slapstick, Vaudeville, Hope & Crosby stylings, and general entertainment spoofs together to produce a whole new way to grab audiences. It was also a show able to entertain the young, but at the same time ensnare grown-ups who are not afraid to laugh at life & death. Its adult humor and historical references were lost on children, but gave the show limitless moments of comedy at other peoples expense. The only downside of the show in my opinion was that it was canceled ... ohh yeah and the episodes focusing on Meg Griffin (pee-eew!!!).P.S. - To respond to a previous opinion, the show didn't change after Season 1, it just expanded. The sexual humor was as integral as the slapstick or the fantasy aspects. The show was intended to use cheap jokes, and illogical (or stupid) story lines to present its comedy. (MadTV is also hilarious)-- Brian & Stewie rock !!!

(E.T. runs across the screen screaming)Its sooo random and its the funniest thing ive ever seen in my life, how they made fun of Randy Newman in that episode is also hilarious.Even tho Da Boom was great, the greatest episode definitely has to be the banned one, "When You Wish Upon a Weinstein."
